\section*{Analogy/Reference Tables}

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline 
$\textbf{monic}$ & $\textbf{characteristic arrow}$ & $\textbf{subobject classifier}$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$\tau:F\hookrightarrow G$ & $(\chi_{\tau})_{V}(x)=\{U\subseteq V\mid G_{U}^{V}(x)\in F(U)$ & $\Omega(V)$ is the set of all $V$-sieves\tabularnewline
\hline 
$i:(X,\lambda)\to(Y,\mu)$  & $\chi_{i}(y)=\{m\mid\mu_{m}(y)\in X\}$  & $L_{m}$ set of all left ideals\tabularnewline
\hline 
$k:(A,q)\to(B,p)$ & $\chi_{k}(b)=(p(b),[p(A\cap U_{b})]_{p(b)})$ & $B_{\Omega}=\bigcup\limits _{x\in X}\Omega_{x}$\tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}\tabularnewline
\tabularnewline
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline 
$\top:1\to\Omega$ & $\bot:1\to\Omega$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$\top_{U}(0)=\mathbf{O}(V)$ (varies with $U$) & $\mathbf{O}(\emptyset)$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
$\top(0)=M$ (fixed) & $\bot(x)=\emptyset$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$\top(x)=(x,[X]_{x})$ (varies with $x$) & $\bot(x)=(x,[\emptyset]_{x})$\tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\pagebreak{}


\part{Presheaf Topoi}

Let's discuss a few examples of presheaf categories and describe them
as elementary topoi. Recall that an elementary topos is a cartesian
closed category $\mathbf{C}$ which has a subobject classifier $\Omega$.
So we just need to show that the category has:
\begin{enumerate}
\item pullbacks and a terminal object (finitely complete).
\item an exponential object (finitely complete + exponential object = cartesian
closed).
\item a subobject classifier. 
\end{enumerate}

\section{$\mathbf{Set\times Set}$}

\begin{example} Let $\mathbf{C}$ be a $\emph{discrete}$ category
with two objects. So it looks like this: \begin{center} \begin{tikzcd} \bullet \arrow[loop left,"1_{\bullet}"] & \bullet \arrow[loop right,"1_{\bullet}"] \end{tikzcd} \end{center}

\begin{flushleft}
Thus, the presheaf category $\mathbf{Set^{\mathbf{C}}}$ is just $\mathbf{Set\times Set}$.
Here is what the objects and morphisms look like:
\par\end{flushleft}

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
$\underline{\textbf{Objects}}$ &  &  &  & $\underline{\textbf{Morphisms}}$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} A & B \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} A \arrow[r,"f"] & C \\ B \arrow[r,"g" swap]  & D \end{tikzcd}\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
object $(A,B)$ &  &  &  & arrow $(f,g)$\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}


\subsubsection{terminal object}

A terminal object in this category is a pair $(\{0\},\{0\})$ of terminal
objects in $\mathbf{Set}$. 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} {0} & {0} \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

pullback

Given two morphisms $(f,g):(A,B)\to(E,F)$ and $(h,k):(C,D)\to(E,F)$,
the pullback is just a pair of pullbacks in $\mathbf{Set}$.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} P \arrow[d,"i" swap] \arrow[r,"j"] & C \arrow[d,"h"] \\ A \arrow[r,"f" swap] & E \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} Q \arrow[d,"u" swap] \arrow[r,"v"] & D \arrow[d,"k"] \\ B \arrow[r,"g" swap] & F \end{tikzcd}\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}


\subsubsection{exponential object}

$(A,B)^{(C,D)}=(A^{C},B^{D})$ 


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

The subobject classifier is a pair $(\Omega,\Omega)$ of subobject
classifiers in $\mathbf{Set}$.

\end{example}


\section{$\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{n}}$}


\subsection{Arrow Category}

\begin{example} Let $\mathbf{2}$ be a category with only two objects
$0$ and $1$, and only one non-identity morphism, $0\to1$. This
category is typically called the $\textbf{arrow category}$, and it
looks like this:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} 0 \arrow[loop above, " id_0 "] \arrow[r] & 1 \arrow[loop above, "id_1 "] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}$\mathbf{Set^{2}}$
is called the $\textbf{arrow category}$ of $\mathbf{Set}$. In general,
for any category $\mathbf{C}$, the presheaf category $\mathbf{C^{2}}$
is called the $\textbf{arrow category}$ of $\mathbf{C}$. How do
we describe objects and morphisms in $\mathbf{Set^{2}}$? Here's how:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
$\underline{\textbf{Objects}}$ &  &  &  & $\underline{\textbf{Morphisms}}$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} S_0 \arrow[r,"S_{01}"] & S_1 \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} S_0 \arrow[d,"f_{0}" swap] \arrow[r," S_{01} "] & S_{1} \arrow[d,"f_{1}"] \\ T_{0} \arrow[r," T_{01} " swap] & T_{1} \end{tikzcd}\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
object $S_{01}$ &  &  &  & arrow $(f_{0},f_{1})$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Here, $S_{0},S_{1},T_{0},T_{1}$ are sets, and $f_{0},f_{1},S_{01},T_{01}$
are functions. We now describe the topos structure of $\mathbf{Set^{2}}$. 


\subsubsection{terminal object}

The terminal object $1$ is the identity function from the terminal
set to itself $id_{\{0\}}:\{0\}\to\{0\}$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} \{ 0 \} \arrow[r, "id_{ \{ 0 \} }"] & \{ 0 \} \end{tikzcd}\end{center}


\subsubsection{pullback}

Given two morphisms $(f_{0},f_{1}):S_{01}\to T_{01}$ and $(g_{0},g_{1}):R_{01}\to T_{01}$,
we obtain part of a cube

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[row sep=scriptsize, column sep=scriptsize] & & & R_0 \arrow[dl," R_{01} " swap] \arrow[dd, " g_0 "] \\ & & R_1 \\ & S_0 \arrow[dl, " S_{01} ", near start, swap] \arrow[rr," f_0 ", near start] & & T_0 \arrow[dl, " T_{01} ", near start] \\ S_1 \arrow[rr, " f_1 ", swap] & & T_1 \arrow[from=uu, crossing over, " g_1 ", near start] \end{tikzcd}\end{center} 

to complete the cube, form the pullbacks

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} Z_0 \arrow[d," q_0 " swap] \arrow[r," p_0 "] & R_0 \arrow[d," g_0 "] \\ S_0 \arrow[r," f_0 " swap] & T_0 \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} Z_1 \arrow[d," q_1 " swap] \arrow[r," p_1 "] & R_1 \arrow[d," g_1 "] \\ S_1 \arrow[r," f_1 " swap] & T_1 \end{tikzcd}\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

in $\mathbf{Set}$, and now we get something that looks like this 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[row sep=scriptsize, column sep=scriptsize] & Z_0 \arrow[dl," Z_{01} " swap] \arrow[rr," p_0 "] \arrow[dd," q_0 " near end, swap] & & R_0 \arrow[dl," R_{01} " swap] \arrow[dd, " g_0 "] \\ Z_1  \arrow[rr, crossing over, " p_1 " near end] \arrow[dd," q_1 " swap] & & R_1 \\ & S_0 \arrow[dl, " S_{01} " near start, swap] \arrow[rr," f_0 " near start] & & T_0 \arrow[dl, " T_{01} " near start] \\ S_1 \arrow[rr, " f_1 " swap] & & T_1 \arrow[from=uu, crossing over, " g_1 " near start]\\ \end{tikzcd}\end{center} 

Here, $Z_{01}$ is uniquely determined by the universal property of
$Z_{1}$. Let's understand why this is. All we need to show is that
$Z_{0}$ is a contender, i.e.:
\[
f_{1}\circ S_{01}\circ q_{0}=T_{01}\circ g_{0}\circ p_{0}
\]


We know that $f_{1}\circ S_{01}=T_{01}\circ f_{0}$ and $f_{0}\circ q_{0}=g_{0}\circ p_{0}$
by the commutative diagrams, so using this we get:
\[
f_{1}\circ S_{01}\circ q_{0}=T_{01}\circ f_{0}\circ q_{0}=T_{01}\circ g_{0}\circ p_{0}
\]


And we are done.


\subsubsection{exponential object}


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

The object $\Omega$ is the function $\Omega_{01}:\Omega_{0}\to\Omega_{1}$
where:
\[
\Omega_{0}=\{0,\frac{1}{2},1\}\mbox{ and }\Omega_{1}=\{0,1\}
\]
\[
\Omega_{01}(0)=0\mbox{, }\Omega_{01}(\frac{1}{2})=1\mbox{, and }\Omega(1)=1
\]


The classifier arrow $\top:1\to\Omega$, is given by a pair 
\[
\top_{0}:\{0\}\to\Omega_{0}\mbox{ \ensuremath{\mid}\ }\top_{0}(0)=1
\]
\[
\top_{1}:\{0\}\to\Omega_{1}\mbox{ \ensuremath{\mid} }\top_{1}(0)=1
\]
 

The reason we need an extra element $\frac{1}{2}$ in the domain is
because we might have a subobject $(i_{0},i_{1}):S_{01}\to T_{01}$,
with $i_{0}$ and $i_{1}$ being inclusions, that looks like this:

\hfill \break \hfill \break

\begin{tikzpicture} \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(0,0)(4,0)(4,8)(0,8)} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$y$] (y) at (2,5) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$z$] (z) at (2,7) {} node[label=below:$ T_0 $] (C) at (1,8) {};  \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(1,1)(3,1)(3,4)(1,4)}          node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (x) at (2,3) {} node[label=below:$ S_0 $] (A) at (1.25,3) {}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(8,0) (12,0) (12, 8) (8,8)} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$ T_{01}(y) $] (y') at (10,4) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$T_{01}(z)$] (z') at (10,7) {} node[label=below:$T_1$] (D) at (9,8) {};     \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(9,1) (11,1) (11, 4) (9,4)}  node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$T_{01}(x) \text{=} S_{01}(x)$] (x') at (10,2) {} node[label=below:$ S_1 $] (B) at (9.25,3) {}    ; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x) edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {} (x'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (y) edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {} (y'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (z) edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {} (z'); \end{tikzpicture} 

\hfill \break \hfill \break

Let's see what goes wrong if $\Omega$ is just a function $id_{\{0,1\}}:\{0,1\}\to\{0,1\}$:
Given the subobject $(i_{0},i_{1}):S_{01}\to T_{01}$ which we drew
above, we could try defining a characteristic function $\chi_{_{S_{01}}}\vcentcolon=(\chi_{_{0}},\chi_{_{1}}):T_{01}\to id_{\{0,1\}}$
by letting $\chi_{_{0}}=\chi_{_{S_{0}}}$ and $\chi_{_{1}}=\chi_{_{S_{1}}}$
(i.e. the characteristic functions in set). But then this wouldn't
be a commutative diagram: $\chi_{_{S_{0}}}$

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} S_{01} \arrow[d,"!" swap] \arrow[r, "  (i_0 \text{,} i_1)  "] & T_{01} \arrow[d," \chi _{_{S_{01}}} "] \\ 1 \arrow[r," \top " swap] & \Omega \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

$T_{01}(y)$ is sent to $1$, since it is contained in $S_{1}$, and
$y$ to $0$, since it is not contained in $S_{0}$. This is why we
need to introduce a new element $\frac{1}{2}$ in the domain of $\Omega_{01}$.
The idea is that the element $y$ will be contained in $S_{1}$, but
not yet! In general, an element $t\in T_{0}$ is classified in three
ways
\begin{enumerate}
\item $t\in S_{0}$, or
\item $t\notin S_{0}$, but $T_{01}(t)\in S_{1}$, or
\item $t\notin S_{0}$, and $T_{01}(t)\notin S_{1}$
\end{enumerate}
define $\chi_{_{0}}:T_{0}\to\Omega_{0}$ by

\[
\chi_{_{0}}(x)=\begin{cases}
1 & \emph{\emph{(1) holds}}\\
\frac{1}{2} & \emph{\emph{(2) holds}}\\
0 & \emph{\emph{(3) holds}}
\end{cases}
\]


and define $\chi_{_{1}}:T_{1}\to\Omega_{1}$ to be the characteristic
function of $S_{1}$ in $\mathbf{Set}$, $\chi_{_{S_{1}}}$.

Now form the cube demonstrates $(\chi_{_{0}},\chi_{_{1}})$ is the
unique arrow that corresponds to the monic $(i_{0},i_{1})$ .

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[row sep=scriptsize, column sep=scriptsize] & S_0 \arrow[dl," S_{01} " swap] \arrow[rr," i_0 "] \arrow[dd," ! " near end, swap] & & T_0 \arrow[dl," T_{01} " swap] \arrow[dd, " \chi _{_{0}} ", shift right=1] \\ S_1 \arrow[rr, crossing over, " i_1 " near end] \arrow[dd," ! " swap] & & T_q \\ & \{ 0 \} \arrow[dl, "id_{ \{ 0 \} }" near start, swap] \arrow[rr," \top _0 " near start] & & \Omega _0 \arrow[dl, " \Omega _{01} " near start] \\ \{ 0 \}  \arrow[rr, " \top _1 " swap] & & \Omega_{1} \arrow[from=uu, crossing over, " \chi _{_{1}} " near start]\\ \end{tikzcd}\end{center} 

\end{example}


\subsection{``Sets through time''}

\begin{example} We can easily generalize everything we did in the
arrow category of set by replacing the poset category $\mathbf{2}$
with the poset $\boldsymbol{\omega}$, i.e. the poset of all finite
ordinals under their natural ordering. It looks like this:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} 0 \arrow[loop above, " id_0 "] \arrow[r] & 1 \arrow[r] \arrow[loop above, "id_1 "] & 2 \arrow[r] \arrow[loop above, "id_2 "] & \cdots \arrow[r] & n \arrow[loop above, "id_n "] \arrow[r] & n+1 \arrow[loop above, "id_{n+1}"]  \arrow[r] & \cdots \end{tikzcd}\end{center}How
do we describe objects and morphisms in the presheaf category $\mathbf{Set}^{\boldsymbol{\omega}}$,
here's how:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
$\underline{\textbf{Objects}}$ &  &  &  & $\underline{\textbf{Morphisms}}$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} S_{0}  \arrow[r, " S_{01} "] & S_{1} \arrow[r, " S_{12} "]  & S_2 \arrow[r, "S_{23}"] & \cdots  \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} S_{0}  \arrow[r, " S_{01} "] \arrow[d," f_0 "] & S_{1} \arrow[r, " S_{12} "] \arrow[d," f_1 "] & S_2 \arrow[r, "S_{23}"] \arrow[d," f_2 "] & \cdots \\  T_{0}  \arrow[r, " T_{01} " swap] & T_{1} \arrow[r, " T_{12} " swap]  & T_2 \arrow[r, "T_{23}" swap] & \cdots  \end{tikzcd} \tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
object $(S_{01},S_{12},\dots)$ &  &  &  & arrow $(f_{0},f_{1},\dots)$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Here, $S_{0},S_{1},\dots,T_{0},T_{1},\dots$ are sets, and $f_{0},f_{1},\dots,S_{01},S_{12},\dots,T_{01},T_{12},\dots$
are functions. It has been suggested by Lawvere that such an object
$(S_{01},S_{12},\dots)$ be considered as a ``set through time'',
where each $S_{n}$ is regarded as the state of the variable set $S$
at the (discrete) time $n$. If $m<n-1$, we define: 
\[
S_{mn}\vcentcolon=S_{(n-1)n}\circ\cdots\circ S_{m(m+1)}
\]


For example, $S_{02}=S_{12}\circ S_{01}$. We now describe the topos
structure of $\mathbf{Set}^{\boldsymbol{\omega}}$. 


\subsubsection{terminal object}

The terminal object $1$ is simply $(id_{\{0\}},id_{\{0\}},\dots)$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} \{ 0 \}  \arrow[r, " id_{ \{ 0 \} } "] & \{ 0 \}  \arrow[r, " id_{ \{ 0 \} } "]  & \{ 0 \}  \arrow[r, " id_{ \{ 0 \} } "] & \cdots  \end{tikzcd} \end{center}


\subsubsection{pullback}

Pullbacks in $\mathbf{Set}^{\boldsymbol{\omega}}$ are constructed
very similarly to the arrow category of $\mathbf{Set}$. Given two
morphisms $(f_{0},f_{1},f_{2},\dots):(S_{01},S_{12},\dots)\to(T_{01},T_{12},\dots)$
and $(g_{0},g_{1},g_{2},\dots):(R_{01},R_{12},\dots)\to(T_{01},T_{12},\dots)$
we first find the pullbacks at each $n$:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 &  &  &  &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} Z_0 \arrow[d," q_0 " swap] \arrow[r," p_0 "] & R_0 \arrow[d," g_0 "] \\ S_0 \arrow[r," f_0 " swap] & T_0 \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} Z_1 \arrow[d," q_1 " swap] \arrow[r," p_1 "] & R_1 \arrow[d," g_1 "] \\ S_1 \arrow[r," f_1 " swap] & T_1 \end{tikzcd} &  &  & $\cdots$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

in $\mathbf{Set}$, and by the universal properties of $Z_{1},Z_{2},\dots$,
we get unique maps $Z_{01}:Z_{0}\to Z_{1}$, $Z_{12}:Z_{1}\to Z_{2}$,
and so on. The pullback then is $(Z_{01},Z_{12},\dots)$.


\subsubsection{exponential object}


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

In $\mathbf{Set}^{\boldsymbol{\omega}}$, $\Omega$ is the object
$(\Omega_{01},\Omega_{12},\dots)$ where:
\[
\{\emptyset,0,1,2,\dots\}=\Omega_{0}=\Omega_{1}=\Omega_{2}=\dots
\]
\[
\Omega_{01}(\emptyset)=\emptyset\mbox{, }\Omega_{01}(0)=0,\mbox{\mbox{ }}\Omega_{01}(1)=0,\mbox{\mbox{ }}\Omega_{01}(2)=1,\mbox{ }\Omega_{01}(3)=2,\mbox{\mbox{ }\ensuremath{\dots}}
\]
\[
\Omega_{12}(\emptyset)=\emptyset\mbox{, }\Omega_{12}(0)=0,\mbox{\mbox{ }}\Omega_{12}(1)=0,\mbox{\mbox{ }}\Omega_{12}(2)=1,\mbox{ }\Omega_{12}(3)=2,\mbox{\mbox{ }\ensuremath{\dots}}
\]
\[
\dots
\]
 

The classifier arrow $\top:1\to\Omega$, is given by: 
\[
\top_{0}:\{0\}\to\Omega_{0}\mbox{ \ensuremath{\mid}\ }\top_{0}(0)=0
\]
\[
\top_{1}:\{0\}\to\Omega_{1}\mbox{ \ensuremath{\mid} }\top_{1}(0)=0
\]
\[
\dots
\]
 

\hfill \break \hfill \break

\begin{tikzpicture}[scale = 1/2] 

\node[] (u) at (1,7.5) {\large $T_{0}$};
\node[] (u) at (9,7.5) {\large $T_{1}$};
\node[] (u) at (17,7.5) {\large $T_{2}$};
\node[] (u) at (25,7.5) {\large $T_{3}$};

\node[] (u) at (2,1.5) {\large $S_{0}$};
\node[] (u) at (10,1.5) {\large $S_{1}$};
\node[] (u) at (18,1.5) {\large $S_{2}$};
\node[] (u) at (26,1.5) {\large $S_{3}$};

\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (x) at (2,8) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$T_{01}(x)$] (x') at (10,6.5) {}; 
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$T_{02}(x)$] (x'') at (18,5.5) {}; 
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$T_{03}(x)$] (x''') at (26,3.5) {};


\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(0,0)(4,0)(4,8)(0,8)};  
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(1,1)(3,1)(3,4)(1,4)}; 
         
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(8,0) (12,0) (12, 8) (8,8)};
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(9,1) (11,1) (11, 4) (9,4)};

\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(16,0) (20,0) (20, 8) (16,8)};
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(17,1) (19,1) (19, 4) (17,4)};

\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(24,0) (28,0) (28, 8) (24,8)};
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(25,1) (27,1) (27, 4) (25,4)};
 

\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x) edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {$$} (x'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x') edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {$$} (x''); 
\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x'') edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {$$} (x'''); \end{tikzpicture} 

\hfill \break \hfill \break

The characteristic function $\chi_{_{S}}=(\chi_{_{0}},\chi_{_{1}},\dots)$
has a nice interpretation. For example, in the image above, $x\notin S_{0}$,
but $T_{03}(x)\in S_{3}$. We think of this as saying, ``$x$ is
in $S$ three seconds later''. So we set $\chi_{_{0}}(x)=3$ 

\end{example}


\section{$\mathbf{M}$-set}

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node (t) at (6.25,2.5) {{$ \bullet $}}; \node (t') at (6.16,4.2) {{\small $ 1 ( \bullet ) $}}; \node (t'') at (6.093,5.12) {{\scriptsize $ 2( \bullet ) $}}; \node (t''') at (6.05,5.55) {{\tiny $ 3( \bullet ) $}};   \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(2,2)(10,2)(10,10)(2,10)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(4,4)(8,4)(8,8)(4,8)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5,5)(7,5)(7,7)(5,7)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5.5,5.5)(6.5,5.5)(6.5,6.5)(5.5,6.5)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5.75,5.75)(6.25,5.75)(6.25,6.25)(5.75,6.25)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5.87,5.87)(6.13,5.87)(6.13,6.13)(5.87,6.13)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5.95,5.95)(6.07,5.95)(6.07,6.07)(5.95,6.07)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5.99,5.99)(6.03,5.99)(6.03,6.03)(5.99,6.03)};  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (t) edge[bend right=40] node[right] { \scriptsize $$} (t'');   \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (t) edge[shorten >=-.5 , bend right = 10] node[right] { \scriptsize $$} (t'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (t) edge[shorten >=-.5 , bend right=70] node[right] { \scriptsize $$} (t'''); \end{tikzpicture} \end{center} 

\begin{example} Let $M$ be a monoid (which may be thought of as
a category with one object) an object in $\mathbf{Set}^{M}$ is called
an $M$-set. We can think of an $M$-set as a pair $(X,\lambda)$,
where $\lambda:M\times X\to X$ is a function such that gives us for
each $m$ a function $\lambda_{m}$ such that:
\begin{itemize}
\item $\lambda_{e}(x)=x$ for $e$ the identity in $M$.
\item $\lambda_{m\cdot n}=\lambda_{m}\circ\lambda_{n}$ 
\end{itemize}
A morphism $f:(X,\lambda)\to(Y,\mu)$ is an equivariant, or action-preserving
function $f:X\to Y$, i.e. one such that for all $m\in M$, the following
diagram commutes:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} X \arrow[d," \lambda _m " swap] \arrow[r,"f"] & Y \arrow[d," \mu _m "] \\ X \arrow[r,"f" swap] & Y \end{tikzcd}\end{center}


\subsubsection{terminal object}

A terminal object in this category is $(\{0\},\lambda)$, where $\{0\}$
is the terminal object in $\mathbf{Set}$ and $\lambda_{m}(0)=0$
for all $m\in M$. 


\subsubsection{pullback}

Given arrows $g:(Y,\mu)\to(Z,\gamma)$ and $f:(X,\lambda)\to(Z,\gamma)$,
the pullback of $f$ and $g$ is $(X\times_{Z}Y,\delta)$, where $X\times_{Z}Y$
is the pullback of $f$ and $g$ in $\mathbf{Set}$, and $\delta_{m}=\lambda_{m}\times\mu_{m}$. 


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{left ideal}$ of a monoid $M$ is a subset
$I$ of $M$ which is closed under left-multiplication, i.e. $m\cdot i\in I$
for all $i\in I$ and $m\in M$. If the monoid is commutative, we
will drop the adjective and just say ``ideal''.

\begin{rem} 

Don't get this confused with left ideals in ring theory. Every ideal
in a ring is a left ideal of the underlying monoid $(R,\cdot,1)$,
but there are usually many more ideals of the underlying monoid that
are not ideals of the ring. This is because an ideal $J$ in a ring
is required to be compatible with the underlying group $(R,+,0)$
of the ring, i.e. non-empty and for all $x,y\in J$, $x-y\in J$.

\end{rem}

\end{defn}

Define $\Omega=(L_{M},\omega)$ where $L_{M}$ is the set of left
ideals of $M$, and $\omega(I)=I:m$, where $I:m$ is defined as $\{n\in M\mid n\cdot m\in I\}$.
The classifier arrow $\top:1\to\Omega$ is the function that picks
out the largest left ideal of $M$, namely $\top(0)=M$. Here are
some important facts about $I:m$:
\begin{itemize}
\item $m\in I$ if and only if $I:m=M$.
\item If $m\in I'$ and $I'\cap I=\emptyset$, then $I:m=\emptyset$.
\item $\emptyset:m=\emptyset$ and $M:m=M$.
\item If $M$ is a $\emph{commutative}$ monoid, then $I\subseteq I:m$
for all $m\in M$.
\end{itemize}
Let's try to understand how the subobject classifier works. If $i:(X,\lambda)\to(Y,\mu)$
is monic, then we may assume that $X$ is a subset of $Y$ and the
action $\mu$ of $Y$ restricts to the action $\lambda$ of $X$.
Since $i$ is equivariant, for each $m\in M$, the action $\lambda_{m}$
must map an element in $X$ to another element in $X$. On the other
hand, $\mu_{m}$ might map an element in $Y$ to an element in $X$.
The character $\chi_{i}:(Y,\mu)\to\Omega$ of $k$ is defined by $\chi_{i}(y)=\{m\mid\mu_{m}(y)\in X\}$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node (S) at (1.4,3) {\LARGE $X$}; \node (S') at (1,8) {\LARGE $Y$}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(0,0)(4,0)(4,8)(0,8)}  node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$y$] (z) at (2,7) {};  \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(1,1)(3,1)(3,4)(1,4)}          node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (x) at (1.5,2) {};  \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$y'$] (y') at (2,4) {};       \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$x'$] (x') at (2.8,3) {}    ; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x) edge[bend right=40] node[below] {$ \lambda _{m} $} (x');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (z) edge[bend right=30] node[left] {$ \mu _{m}  $} (y'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (y') edge[bend right=30] node[right] {$ ! \exists \mu _{m^{-1}} $} (z);\end{tikzpicture} \end{center}

Since the classifier arrow $\top:1\to\Omega$ picks out the largest
ideal $M$, then if $y\in X$, $\chi_{i}(y)$ must be $M$. This is
true since $\mu_{m}$ restricts to $\lambda_{m}$ on $X$, and $\lambda_{m}$
maps every element in $X$ to another element in $X$ by the equivariance
of $i$. Notice that if $y\notin X$ and $\mu_{m}$ maps $y$ into
$X$, then $\mu_{m^{-1}}$ cannot exist, which just means that $m$
is not invertible. Also notice that if $y\notin X$ and $\mu_{m}$
maps $y$ into $X$, then $\mu_{n\cdot m}=\mu_{n}\circ\mu_{m}$ maps
$y$ into $X$ too, so $\chi_{i}(y)$ really is a left ideal. 


\subsubsection{exponential object}

Given $(X,\lambda)$ and $(Y,\mu)$, we define the exponential $(Y,\mu)^{(X,\lambda)}=(E,\sigma)$,
where $E$ is the set of equivariant maps $f$ of the form $f:(M,\cdot)\times(X,\lambda)\to(Y,\mu)$
and $\sigma_{m}:E\to E$ takes such an $f$ to the function $\sigma_{m}(f):M\times X\to Y$
given by $g(n,x)=f(m\cdot n,x)$. The evaluation arrow $ev:(E,\sigma)\times(X,\lambda)\to(Y,\mu)$
have $ev(f,x)=f(e,x)$. Then given an arrow $f:(X,\lambda)\times(Y,\mu)\to(Z,\delta)$,
the exponential adjoint $\hat{f}:(X,\lambda)\to(Z,\delta)^{(Y,\mu)}$
takes $x$ to the equivariant map $\hat{f_{x}}:M\times Y\to Z$ having
$\hat{f_{x}}(m,y)=f(\lambda_{m}(x),y)$. Categories of the form $\mathbf{M}$-set
frovide a rich source of examples, particularly of topoi that have
``non-classical'' properties. 

\end{example}

\begin{example} $(\mathbb{N},+,0)$ is the monoid of natural numbers
under addtion. The set of left ideals are of the form $[n]=\{n,n+1,\dots\}$,
hence the set of left ideals corresponds with the set of natural numbers.
The ideal $[n]:m$ is also easy to describe. 

\begin{center}
If $m\geq n$, then $[n]:m=\mathbb{N}$. 
\par\end{center}

\begin{center}
If $m<n$, then $[n]:m=[n-m]$. 
\par\end{center}

\end{example}

\begin{example} Recall the monoid from the other set of notes:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} \bullet \arrow[loop right, "f"] \arrow[loop left, "1_{\bullet}"] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

with this multiplication table:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c}
$\circ$ & $e$ & $f$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$e$ & $e$ & $f$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$f$ & $f$ & $f$\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\begin{flushleft}
Let's denote this monoid $\mathbf{G_{2}}$. Now, what is the subobject
classifier in the category of $\mathbf{G_{2}}$-sets? We need to compute
the left ideals of $\mathbf{G_{2}}$, and the corresponding action.
This is presented in the table below: 
\par\end{flushleft}

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c}
$\omega$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{f\}$ & $\emptyset$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$e$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{f\}$ & $\emptyset$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$f$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\emptyset$\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Let's go over an example of a $\mathbf{G_{2}}$-set $Y$ with six
elements. So suppose $Y=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$, i.e. just a set with five
elements. We need two functions $\mu_{f}$,$\mu_{e}$ from $Y$ to
$Y$ which satisfy the following identities:
\[
\mu_{e}\circ\mu_{f}=\mu_{f}\circ\mu_{e}=\mu_{f}
\]
\[
\mu_{e}\circ\mu_{e}=\mu_{e}
\]
\[
\mu_{f}\circ\mu_{f}=\mu_{f}
\]


These work:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$1$] (a) at (1,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$2$] (b) at (2,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$3$] (c) at (3,3) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$4$] (d) at (4,3) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$5$] (e) at (5,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$6$] (f) at (6,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$1$] (a') at (1,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$2$] (b') at (2,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$3$] (c') at (3,0) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$4$] (d') at (4,0) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$5$] (e') at (5,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$6$] (f') at (6,0) {}; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (a) edge[out=250,in=80] node[left] {$ \mu _{f} $} (a'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (b) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (b'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (c) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (d) edge[out=270,in=83] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (e) edge[out=270,in=75] node[above] {$$} (c'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (f) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (f');  \end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$1$] (a) at (1,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$2$] (b) at (2,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$3$] (c) at (3,3) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$4$] (d) at (4,3) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$5$] (e) at (5,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$6$] (f) at (6,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$1$] (a') at (1,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$2$] (b') at (2,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$3$] (c') at (3,0) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$4$] (d') at (4,0) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$5$] (e') at (5,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$6$] (f') at (6,0) {}; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (a) edge[out=250,in=80] node[left] {$ \mu _{e} $} (a'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (b) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (b'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (c) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (d) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (d');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (e) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (e'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (f) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (f');  \end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

Now, let's find a subobject $i:(X,\lambda)\to(Y,\mu)$ of $(Y,\mu)$.
Since $i$ is monic, can assume that $X$ is a subset of $Y$, say
$X=\{1,2,3,4\}$. We mentioned earlier that we can then assume that
$\lambda_{m}$ is just the restriction of $\mu_{m}$ onto $X$. Let's
explicitly show why this is the case. So we need two functions $\lambda_{f}$,$\lambda_{e}$
from $X$ to $X$ which satisfies the following identities:

\[
\lambda_{e}\circ\lambda_{f}=\lambda_{f}\circ\lambda_{e}=\lambda_{f}
\]
\[
\lambda_{e}\circ\lambda_{e}=\lambda_{e}
\]
\[
\lambda_{f}\circ\lambda_{f}=\lambda_{f}
\]


We also need $\lambda_{f}$,$\lambda_{e}$ to satisfy the following
commutative diagrams:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} \bullet \arrow[d,"f" swap] && X \arrow[r, hookrightarrow, "i"] \arrow[d, "\lambda _{f}" swap] & Y \arrow[d, "\mu _{f}"] \\ \bullet &&  X \arrow[r, hookrightarrow, "i" swap]  & Y \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} \bullet \arrow[d,"id_{\bullet}" swap] && X \arrow[r, hookrightarrow, "i"] \arrow[d, "\lambda _{e}" swap] & Y \arrow[d, "\mu _{e}"] \\ \bullet &&  X \arrow[r, hookrightarrow, "i" swap]  & Y \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

The arrows $f:\bullet\to\bullet$ and $id_{\bullet}:\bullet\to\bullet$
are there to remind the reader that $i$ is a natural transformation.
Now since we already specified what $i$ is the commutative diagrams
above force us to take:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$1$] (a) at (1,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$2$] (b) at (2,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$3$] (c) at (3,3) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$4$] (d) at (4,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$1$] (a') at (1,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$2$] (b') at (2,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$3$] (c') at (3,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$4$] (d') at (4,0) {};\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (a) edge[out=250,in=80] node[left] {$ \lambda _{e} $} (a'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (b) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (b'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (c) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (d) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (d'); \end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

Now, let's highlight the subset $X$ of $Y$ in red: 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$1$] (a) at (1,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$2$] (b) at (2,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$3$] (c) at (3,3) {};\node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$4$] (d) at (4,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$5$] (e) at (5,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$6$] (f) at (6,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$1$] (a') at (1,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$2$] (b') at (2,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$3$] (c') at (3,0) {};\node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$4$] (d') at (4,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$5$] (e') at (5,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$6$] (f') at (6,0) {}; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (a) edge[out=250,in=80] node[left] {$ \mu _{f} | _{X} = \lambda _{f} $} (a'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (b) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (b'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (c) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (d) edge[out=270,in=83] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (e) edge[out=270,in=75] node[above] {$$} (c'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (f) edge[out=250,in=80] node[right] {$ \mu _{f} $} (f');  \end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$1$] (a) at (1,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$2$] (b) at (2,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$3$] (c) at (3,3) {};\node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$4$] (d) at (4,3) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$5$] (e) at (5,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$6$] (f) at (6,3) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$1$] (a') at (1,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$2$] (b') at (2,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$3$] (c') at (3,0) {};\node[circle, fill=red, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$4$] (d') at (4,0) {};\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$5$] (e') at (5,0) {}; \node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$6$] (f') at (6,0) {}; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (a) edge[out=250,in=80] node[left] {$ \mu _{e} | _{X} = \lambda _{e} $} (a'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (b) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (b'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (c) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (c');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (d) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (d');  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (e) edge[out=250,in=80] node[above] {$$} (e'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (f) edge[out=250,in=80] node[right] {$ \mu _{e} $} (f');  \end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

Now, how does $\Omega=(L_{m},\omega)$ classify this subobject? Recall,
that $\chi_{i}(y)=\{m\mid\mu_{m}(y)\in X\}$. So we have:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c}
$\chi_{i}(n)$ & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6\tabularnewline
\hline 
$\chi_{i}$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{e,f\}$ & $\{f\}$ & $\emptyset$\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

So far, this looks similar to how we classified subobjects in $\mathbf{Set^{2}}$,
but there are some important fundamental differences. We will discuss
this more at a later section.

\end{example}


\section{Slice Categories}


\subsection{Bundles }

\begin{samepage}\begin{defn} The $\textbf{slice category}$ $\mathbf{C}/c$
of a category $\mathbf{C}$ over an object $c\in\mathbf{C}$ has
\begin{itemize}
\item objects are all arrows $f$ with codomain $c$.
\item morphisms from $f$ to $f'$ are all arrows $g$ such that $f'\circ g=f$ 
\end{itemize}
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
$\underline{\textbf{Objects}}$ &  &  &  & $\underline{\textbf{Morphisms}}$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} d \arrow[r,"f"] & c \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd}[column sep=small] d \arrow[dr,"f" swap] \arrow[rr,"g"] && d' \arrow[dl,"f'"] \\ & c \end{tikzcd}\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
object $(d,f)$  &  &  &  & morphism $g$\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\begin{note} $\mathbf{C}/c$ is sometimes called the $\textbf{over category}$.

\end{note}

\end{defn}

\end{samepage}

\begin{example} An object $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Set}/S$ can be pictured
like this: \end{example} \hfill \break \hfill \break

\begin{tikzpicture} \node (S) at (1.25,1) {\LARGE $S$}; \node (Bx) at (2,10) {\LARGE $B_{x}$}; \node (By) at (5,10) {\LARGE $B_{y}$}; \node (Bz) at (8,10) {\LARGE $B_{z}$}; \draw [decorate,decoration={brace,amplitude=10pt},xshift=-4pt,yshift=0pt] (0,4.5) -- (0,10.5) node [black,midway,xshift=-0.7cm] (B)  {\LARGE $B$} ; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(1,0)(9,0)(9,2)(5,2.5)(1,2)}   node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$y$] (y) at (5,1.6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$z$] (z) at (8,1) {};  \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(1.5,5)(2.5,5)(2.5,10)(1.5,10)}          node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (x) at (2,1) {}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(4.5,5) (5.5,5) (5.5, 10) (4.5,10)} node[] (yy) at (5,4.6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$y'$] (y') at (5,6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$y''$] (y'') at (5,7.5) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$y'''$] (y''') at (5,9) {} node[] (zz) at (8,4.6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$z'$] (z') at (8,6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$z''$] (z'') at (8,7.5) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$z'''$] (z''') at (8,9) {};     \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(7.5,5) (8.5,5) (8.5, 10) (7.5,10)} node[] (xx) at (2,4.6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x'$] (x') at (2,6) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x''$] (x'') at (2,7.5) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x'''$] (x''') at (2,9) {}   ; \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (xx) edge[] node[right] {\LARGE $p_{x}$} (x); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (yy) edge[] node[right] {\LARGE $p_{y}$} (y); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (zz) edge[] node[right] {\LARGE $p_{z}$} (z); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (B) edge[bend right=30] node[left] {\LARGE $p$} (S); \end{tikzpicture} 

\hfill \break \hfill \break

Let's take a moment to reflect on this image, because it will serve
as a nice visualization tool for other categories. For each element
$s\in S$, there is an associated set $B_{s}$, which is just the
inverse image of $s$ under $p$, i.e. $p^{-1}(s)=B_{s}$. $B_{s}$
is typically called the $\textbf{stalk}$, or $\textbf{fiber}$ of
$p$ over $s$, and elements of $B_{s}$ are called $\emph{germs}$
at $s$. Notice that for any distinct $s,s'\in S$, $B_{s}\cap B_{s'}=\emptyset$,
and that $\bigcup_{s}B_{s}=B$. We also have functions $p_{s}$, which
is just the restriction of $p$ to $B_{s}$. The commutativity condition
for morphisms in the slice category tells us that a morphism from
$(B,p)$ to $(B',p')$ maps at $s$ in $(B,p)$ to germs at $s$ in
$(B',p')$. The whole structure is called a $\textbf{bundle}$ of
sets over the $\textbf{base space}$ $X$, with $B$ being called
the $\textbf{total space}$ and $p$ being called the $\textbf{projection}$.
What do morphisms $(A,q)\to(B,q)$ look like in $\mathbf{Set}/S$?
The commutative diagram tells us that they should be functions $f:A\to B$
that preserve fibers likeso:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=1/2] 

%Nodes

\node[] (yy) at (5,4.7) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (y) at (5,1.6) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$a$] (yyy) at (5,6) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$a'$] (yyyy) at (5,7.5) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$a''$] (yyyyy) at (5,9) {};


\node[] (yy') at (19,4.7) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$f(x)$] (y') at (19,1.6) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$b$] (yyy') at (19,6) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$b'$] (yyyy') at (19,7.5) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$b''$] (yyyyy') at (19,9) {};
 


%Plots

\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(1,0)(9,0)(9,2)(5,2.5)(1,2)};   
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(4.5,5) (5.5,5) (5.5, 10) (4.5,10)};   

\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(15,0)(23,0)(23,2)(19,2.5)(15,2)};   
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(18.5,5) (19.5,5) (19.5, 10) (18.5,10)}; 


%Arrows


\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (yy) edge[] node[right] {\LARGE $$} (y);  

\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (yy') edge[] node[right] {\LARGE $$} (y'); 

\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (yyy) edge[out=10,in=170] node[above] {$$} (yyy'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (yyyy) edge[out=10,in=170] node[above] {$$} (yyyy'); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (yyyyy) edge[out=10,in=170] node[above] {$$} (yyyyy'); 
\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (y) edge[out=10,in=170] node[above] {$$} (y'); 

\end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

Now, let's describe the topos structure of $\mathbf{Set}/S$.


\subsubsection{terminal object}

The terminal object for $\mathbf{Set}/S$ is $(S,id_{S})$. The stalk
of $id_{S}$ over $s$ is $\{s\}$, which is just the terminal object
in $\mathbf{Set}$. So the terminal object in $\mathbf{Set}/S$ is
just a ``bundle'' of terminal objects in $\mathbf{Set}$ over $S$.
A morphism from the terminal object $(S,id_{S})$ to any other object
$(B,p)$ in $\mathbf{Set}/S$ is just a section of $p$. 


\subsubsection{pullback}

Given arrows $f:(B,p)\to(A,q)$ and $g:(C,r)\to(A,q)$, the pullback
object of $f$ and $g$ in $\mathbf{Set}/S$ will have the form $(Z,j)$.
To figure out what this object is, we forget about the arrows $p,q,r,$
and $j$, and compute the object $Z$ by forming the pullback of $f$
and $g$ in $\mathbf{Set}$

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} Z  \arrow[d,"n" swap] \arrow[r,"m"] & B  \arrow[d,"f"] \\ C \arrow[r,"g" swap] & A  \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

Now that we have $Z$, the $j$ is the unique arrow which makes the
following diagram commutative

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} Z  \arrow[dd,"n" swap] \arrow[rr,"m"] \arrow[dr, "j"] && B \arrow[dl,"p"] \arrow[dd,"f"] \\ & S \\ C \arrow[rr,"g" swap] \arrow[ur, "r"] && A \arrow[ul, "q"] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

Now if $B_{s}$, $A_{s}$, $C_{s}$ are the stalks over $s$ for the
bundles $(B,p)$, $(A,q)$, and $(C,r)$ respectively, then the pullback
of 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  & B_{s}  \arrow[d,"f_{s}"] \\ C_{s} \arrow[r,"g_{s}" swap] & A_{s}  \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

is the same as the stalk over $s$ for $(Z,j)$. Thus, the pullback
$(Z,j)$ is a ``bundle'' of pullbacks in $\mathbf{Set}$. 


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

$\Omega$ is $(2\times S,p_{S})$ where $2=\{0,1\}$ and $p_{S}(x,y)=y$.
So the stalk over a typical element $s$ consists of two elements:
$\{0,s\}$ and $\{1,s\}$. The arrow $\top:1\to\Omega$ is a section
of $\Omega$, which is defined by $\top(s)=(1,s)$. $\top$ can be
thought of as a bundle of copies of the set function $\emph{true}$.
Now, given a monic $i:(A,q)\to(B,p)$, we may assume $A\subseteq B$
and $\left.p\right|_{A}=q$. We wish to define the character $\chi_{i}:(B,p)\to\Omega$
so that the following diagram commutes

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} A  \arrow[dd,"q" swap] \arrow[rr,"i"] \arrow[dr, "q"] && B \arrow[dl,"p"] \arrow[dd," \chi _{i}"] \\ & S \\ S \arrow[rr," \top " swap] \arrow[ur, " id_{S} "] && 2 \times S \arrow[ul, " p_{S} "] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

It's easy to see that we get a ``bundle'' of characteristic functions.

\begin{center}

\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=1/2] \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(0,6)(4,6)(4,14)(0,14)} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$a$] (x') at (2,9) {} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$b$] (x'') at (2,13) {};  \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(1,7)(3,7)(3,10)(1,10)}          ;               \node (S) at (5.25,1) {\LARGE $S$}; \node (I) at (17,7) {\LARGE $ \{ 1 \} \times S $}; \node (I) at (17,11) {\LARGE $ \{ 0 \} \times S $}; \node (B) at (1,13) {\LARGE $B$}; \node (B) at (1,13) {\LARGE $B$}; \node (B) at (1.6,8) {\LARGE $A$}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(5,0)(13,0)(13,2)(9,2.5)(5,2)} node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (x) at (8,1) {}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(11,6)(19,6)(19,8)(15,8.5)(11,8)}   node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$ \emph{(1,x)} $] (y) at (14,7) {};  \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(11,10)(19,10)(19,12)(15,12.5)(11,12)}   node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=above:$ \emph{(0,x)}$] (y') at (14,11) {};  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (y) edge[] node[right] {} (x); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (y') edge[] node[right] {} (x); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (x') edge[] node[right] {} (x); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (x'') edge[] node[right] {$$} (x); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x') edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {$true$} (y); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (x'') edge[out=-20, in=160] node[below] {$false$} (y');  \end{tikzpicture} 

\end{center}


\subsection{Etale Spaces}

Now, let's consider an object $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Top}/X$. This time,
$X$ and $B$ are topological spaces and $p$ is continuous. 

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{local homeomorphism}$ is a continuous map
$p:B\to X$ with the additional property that for each point $b\in B$
there exists an open neighborhood $U_{b}$ in $B$ such that $p(U_{b})$
is open in $X$, and $p$ restricts to a homeomorphism $\left.p\right|_{U_{b}}:U_{b}\to p(U_{b})$. 

\begin{rem} Intuitively, a local homeomorphism preserves ``local
structure''. For example, $B$ is locally compact if and only if
$p(B)$ is. 

\end{rem}

\end{defn}

\begin{prop} Let $p:B\to X$ be a local homeomorphism, then $p$
is an open map, i.e. it maps open sets to open sets. \end{prop}

\begin{proof} Let $U$ be open in $B$, we need to show that $p(U)$
is open in $X$. For each $b\in U$, $U\cap U_{b}$ is open in $U_{b}$,
and since homeomorphisms are open maps, $\left.p\right|_{U_{b}}(U\cap U_{b})$
is open in $p(U_{b})$ in the subspace topology. Since $p(U_{b})$
is open in $X$, $p(U\cap U_{b})$ is open in $X$ too. Finally, since
$\bigcup\limits _{b\in U}p(U\cap U_{b})=p(U)$, $p(U)$ is open in
$X$.

\end{proof}

\begin{example} Every \hyperlink{covering map}{covering map} is
a local homeomorphism. \end{example}

\begin{example} If $X$ is a topological space and $Y$ is a discrete
space, then the projection $Y\times X\to X$ is a local homeomorphism.
\end{example}

\begin{example} On the other hand, the projection map $\mathbb{R}\times X\to X$
is never a local homeomorphism, because no product neighborhood is
projected homeomorphically into $X$. For much the same reason, a
nontrivial vector bundle is never a locally homeomorphism either.
\end{example}

\begin{defn} An $\textbf{etale space}$ over $X$ is an object $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Top}/X$
such that $p$ is a local homeomorphism. $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$ is the
category whose objects are pairs $\textbf{etale spaces }$over $X$
and morphisms being the same as in $\mathbf{Top}/X$. 

\begin{rem} $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$ is a full subcategory of $\mathbf{Top}/X$.

\end{rem}

\end{defn}

Here's how $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$ looks as a topos:


\subsubsection{terminal object}

The terminal object for $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$ is $(X,id_{X})$.

\begin{defn} A morphism $s$ from the terminal object $(X,id_{X})$
to any other object $(B,p)$ in $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$ is called a $\textbf{global section}$
of $p$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[column sep=small] X \arrow[dr," id_X " swap] \arrow[rr,"s"] && B \arrow[dl,"p"] \\ & X \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\end{defn}

So a global section is just a continuous map $s:X\to B$ such that
$p\circ s$ is the identity map $id_{X}:X\to X$. We will also be
interested in $\textbf{local sections}$ of $p$, which are continuous
maps defined on an open subset $U\subset X$ to $B$, such that $p\circ s$
is the inclusion $U\hookrightarrow X$. A $\textbf{section}$ of a
local homeomorphism $p$ will always mean a local section $s$ of
$p$ defined on some open subset $U\subset X$. Sometimes the words
section and local section are used interchangeably, however we will
always include the adjective ``global'' when referring to global
sections.

\begin{prop} If $p:B\to X$ is a local homeomorphism and $U\subset X$
is open, the pullback

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} B_U \arrow[d] \arrow[r] & B \arrow[d] \\ U \arrow[r] & X \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

$B_{U}\to U$ is also a local homeomorphism. 

\begin{rem} A local section of $p$ is just a global section of $B_{U}$,
for some open subset $U$ of $X$. \end{rem}

\end{prop}

\begin{prop} If $p:B\to X$ is a local homeomorphism and $b$ is
any element of $B$, then there exists a local section of $p$ defined
on some open subset $V$, such that $b\in s(V)$ \end{prop}

\begin{proof} $\left.p\right|_{U_{b}}^{-1}$ is a local section of
$p$ defined on $p(U_{b})$, it maps $p(b)$ to $b$.\end{proof} 

\begin{defn} We say that $s$ and $t$ have the same $\textbf{germ}$
at a point $x\in X$ when they agree in some open neighborhood of
$x$. We write $[s]\sim_{x}[t]$ if $s$ and $t$ have the same germ
at $x$.\end{defn}

\begin{prop} Given $b\in B$, $x\in X$, with $p(b)=x$, any local
section $s$ of $p$ with $b$ in its image has the same germ as $\left.p\right|_{U_{b}}^{-1}$
at $x$. \end{prop}

\begin{proof}Suppose $s$ maps $x$ to $b$. Set$W=s^{-1}(U_{b})$,
which is an open neighborhood of $x$. Since $s$ and $\left.p\right|_{U_{b}}^{-1}$
agree on $W$, $[s]\sim_{x}[\left.p\right|_{U_{b}}^{-1}]$. \end{proof}

\begin{prop} A local section $s$ of $p$ defined on an open set
$U\subset X$ is an open map. The images $sU$ of all local sections
form a base for the topology of $B$. If $s$ and $t$ are two local
sections, then the set $W=\{x\mid sx=tx\}$ of points where they are
both defined and agree is open in $X$. \end{prop}

\begin{ex} Prove this. \end{ex}

For ease of notation, we simply write $p$ instead of $p|_{U_{b}}$.
Whenever there is a potential source of confusion, we will use $p|_{U_{b}}$.


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

Let $\mathbf{O}(X)$ be the collection of open subset of $X$. Consider
the following equivalence relation on this collection: $U\sim_{x}V$
if and only if there is some open set $W$ such that $x\in W$ and
$U\cap W=V\cap W$. The idea is that $U\sim_{x}V$ when the points
in $U$ that are close to $x$ are the same as those that are in $V$
and close to $x$, i.e. ``locally'' around $x$, $U$ and $V$ look
the same, i.e. the statement $"U=V"$ is ``locally true'' at $x$.
The equivalence class $[U]_{x}=\{V:U\sim_{x}V\}$ is called the germ
of $U$ at $x$. It ``represents'' the collection of all points
in $U$ that are ``close'' to $x$. The stalk then is $\Omega_{x}=\{(x,[U]_{x})\mid U\subseteq X\}$.
Now let 

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
$B_{\Omega}=\bigcup\limits _{x\in X}\Omega_{x}$ be the total space &  &  &  & $p:B_{\Omega}\to X$ the obvious projection map\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Then we have $\Omega=(B_{\Omega},p)$. The topology on the total space
$\hat{\Omega}$ has as base all sets of the form 

\begin{center}
$[U,V]=\{(x,[U]_{x})\mid x\in V$ and $U\subseteq V\}$
\par\end{center}

Here are some important facts about germs of open sets:
\begin{itemize}
\item $[U]_{x}=[X]_{x}$ if and only if $x\in U$, i.e. $[X]_{x}$ is the
collection of all open neighborhoods of $x$.
\item $[U]_{x}=[\emptyset]_{x}$ if and only if $x$ is $\textbf{separated}$
from $U$, i.e. there exists an open neighborhood $V$ of $x$ and
$U\cap V=\emptyset$.
\end{itemize}
\begin{prop}Every open set in $X$ gives rise to a continuous global
section $s_{U}(x)=(x,[U]_{x})$, conversely, if $s:1\to\Omega$ is
any continuous global section of $\Omega$ then $s^{-1}([X,X])=\{x\mid s(x)=(x,[X]_{x})\}$
is open and $s=s_{s^{-1}([X,X])}$. Thus, there is a one to one correspondence
between the truth values in $\mathbf{Top}(X)$ and the open subsets
of $X$. \begin{rem}Compare this with $\mathbf{Bn}(X)$, where we
found that there was a one to one correspondence between truth values
in $\mathbf{Bn}(S)$ and subsets of $S$. \end{rem} \end{prop}

\begin{ex} Prove this.\end{ex}

\begin{example}

Consider the topology on the finite set $X=\{a,b,c\}$ where the open
sets are highlighted in red: \hypertarget{topology1}{}

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  &  \textcolor{red}{ \{ a,b,c \} } \\ \textcolor{red}{ \{ a,b \} } \arrow[ur] & \textcolor{red}{ \{ a,c \} } \arrow[u] & \{ b,c \} \arrow[lu] \\ \textcolor{red}{ \{ a \}} \arrow[u] \arrow[ur] & \{ b \} \arrow[ul] \arrow[ur]  & \textcolor{red}{ \{ c \} } \arrow[u] \arrow[lu] \\ & \textcolor{red}{ \emptyset } \arrow[u] \arrow[lu] \arrow[ru] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

What is the stalk at point $a$? We have two elements:
\[
X\sim_{a}\{a,b\}\sim_{a}\{a,c\}\sim_{a}\{a\}
\]
\[
\emptyset\sim_{a}\{c\}
\]


What is the stalk at point $b$? We have three elements: 
\[
X\sim_{b}\{a,b\}
\]
\[
\{a\}\sim_{b}\{a,c\}
\]
\[
\emptyset\sim_{b}\{c\}
\]


What is the stalk at point $c$? We have two elements: 
\[
X\sim_{c}\{a,c\}\sim_{c}\{c\}
\]
\[
\emptyset\sim_{c}\{a\}\sim_{c}\{a,b\}
\]


So our entire space $\Omega$ consists of 7 elements:

\hfill \break \hfill \break

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture} \node (da) at (1,2) {}; \node (da') at (1,4) {}; \node (db) at (3,2) {}; \node (db') at (3,4) {}; \node (dc) at (5,2) {}; \node (dc') at (5,4) {}; \node (a) at (1,1) {$a$}; \node (b) at (3,1) {$b$}; \node(c) at (5,1) {$c$}; \node (a') at (1,5) {$(a,[ \emptyset ]_{a})$}; \node (b') at (3,5) {$(b,[ \emptyset ]_{b})$}; \node (c') at (5,5) {$(c,[ \emptyset ]_{c})$}; \node (b'') at (3,7) {$(b,[ \{ a \} ]_{b})$}; \node (a''') at (1,9) {$(a,[X]_{a})$}; \node (b''') at (3,9) {$(b,[X]_{b})$}; \node (c''') at (5,9) {$(c,[X]_{c})$}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(0.5,4.5)(5.5,4.5)(5.5,5.5)(0.5,5.5)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(0.5,8.5)(5.5,8.5)(5.5,9.5)(0.5,9.5)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(0.3,8.5)(2.5,6.5)(3.8,6.5)(3.7,7.5)(1.5,9.5)(0.5,9.5)};  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (da') edge[] node[right] {} (da); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (db') edge[] node[right] {} (db); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (dc') edge[] node[right] {} (dc); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (c') edge[] node[right] {} (c'''); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (b') edge[] node[right] {} (b''); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (b'') edge[] node[right] {} (b'''); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (a') edge[] node[right] {} (a'''); \end{tikzpicture} \end{center}

\hfill \break \hfill \break

Notice that for each point in $x\in\Omega$ there exists an open neighborhood
$U_{x}$ (not necessarily unique!) of $b$ such that $p:U_{x}\to p(U_{x})$
is a homeomorphism. In the example above, the three neighborhoods
we picked out are:
\[
[X,X]=\{(a,[X]_{a}),(b,[X]_{b}),(c,[X]_{c})\}
\]
\[
[\emptyset,X]=\{(a,[\emptyset]_{a}),(b,[\emptyset]_{b}),(c,[\emptyset]_{c})\}
\]
\[
[\{a\},\{a,b\}]=\{(a,[X]_{a}),(b,[\{a\}]_{b})\}
\]


Now, you may be wondering what the dotted arrows mean. Well, it turns
out that there is a partial ordering $\leq$ on each stalk $\Omega_{x}$
which comes from the partial ordering $\subseteq$ on $\mathbf{O}(X)$:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c}
$[U]_{x}\leq[V]_{x}$ if and only if there is some open set $W$ such
that $x\in W$ and $U\cap W\subseteq V\cap W$.\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

i.e. if and only if the statement ``$U\subseteq V$'' is locally
true at $x$. We will use this partial ordering to measure ``closeness''. 

\end{example}

Now let's see how the subobject classifier works. The arrow $\top:1\to\Omega$
is the continuous section $\top:X\to B_{\Omega}$ that has $\top(x)=(x,[X]_{x})$,
for all $x\in X$. Now suppose we have a monic arrow $k:(A,q)\to(B,p)$
so that the following diagram commutes:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[column sep=small]  A \arrow[rr,"k", hookrightarrow] \arrow[dr,"q" swap] && B \arrow[dl, "p"] \\ & X \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

We may think of $A$ as an open subset of $B$. The character $\chi_{k}:(B,p)\to\Omega$
associated to the monic $k$ is defined as follows: If $b\in B$,
choose a neighborhood of $U_{b}$ of $b$ on which $p$ restricts
to a homeomorphism $p:U_{b}\to p(U_{b})$. Then $\chi_{k}(b)=(x,[p(A\cap U_{b})]_{x})$,
where $p(b)=x.$ Intuitively, the germ of $p(A\cap U_{b})$ at $x$
represents the set of points in $A$ close to $b$. For example, if
$b\in A$, we would say that $b$ is as close to $A$ as possible,
so this should mean 
\[
(x,[p(A\cap U_{b})]_{x})=(x,[X]_{x})=\top(x)
\]


which is indeed true since $p(A\cap U_{b})$ is an open neighborhood
of $x$. On the other hand, if $b$ is separated from $A$, then we
would say that $b$ is as far away from $A$ as possible, and this
should mean
\[
(x,[p(A\cap U_{b})]_{x})=(x,[\emptyset]_{x})
\]


which again is true. Now in set theory, these are our only two choices;
either $b\in A$ or $b\notin A$. However now, using the partial ordering
$\leq$ on the germs over $x$, we can obtain more subtle distinctions.
Under this partial ordering over a given stalk $\Omega_{x}$, $(x,[X]_{x})$
is always the largest germ, $(x,[\emptyset]_{x})$ is always the smallest
germ, and everything else is in between. Thus, the larger the germ$[p(A\cap U_{b})]_{x}$
is in terms of this ordering, the closer $b$ will be to $A$. 

\begin{example} Continuing on the previous example, how close is
$b$ to the open set $\{a\}$? Well it's certainly not in $\{a\}$,
at the same time, it's not separated from $\{a\}$ either; it's somewhere
in between. Now the open set $\{a\}$ is a subobject of $1$, hence
there exists a unique map $\chi_{\{a\}}:1\to\Omega$, i.e. a continuous
global section of $B_{\Omega}$, and indeed $b$ is mapped to the
germ $(b,[\{a\}]_{b})$.

\end{example}


\subsubsection{exponential object}

...


\section{$\mathbf{Set^{O(X)^{op}}}$}


\subsection{Presheaves and Sheaves}

\begin{defn}$\mathbf{O}(X)$ is the poset category with open subsets
of $X$ as objects and inclusions as morphisms. \begin{rem}$\mathbf{O}(X)$
is an example of a complete heyting algebra, or a poset that is cartesian
closed and with finite sums (finite co-complete).\end{rem}\end{defn}

Recall that a presheaf is just a functor $F$ from a category $\mathbf{C}^{op}$
to the category $\mathbf{Set}$. Historically however, presheaves
were first defined on the category $\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}$. 

\begin{defn} Let $X$ be any topological space. A $\mbox{\textbf{presheaf}}$
$F$ $\textbf{on}$ $X$ assigns to each open set $U$ in $X$ a set,
$F(X)$, and to every pair of nested open sets $U\subset V\subset X$,
a restriction map
\[
F_{U}^{V}:F(V)\to F(U)
\]


satisfying the basic properties that 
\[
F_{U}^{U}=\emph{identity}
\]


and for all $U\subset V\subset W\subset X$, we have
\[
F_{U}^{V}\circ F_{V}^{W}=F_{U}^{W}
\]


The elements $F(U)$ are called sections of $F$ over $U$; elements
of $F(X)$ are called global sections. 

\end{defn}

\begin{ex} Check that this agrees with the functor definition. \end{ex}

Presheaves on a topological space $X$ are top-down constructions;
we can restrict information from larger to smaller sets. However,
many objects in mathematics are bottom-up constructions; they are
defined by locally, which we then piece together to obtain something
global. Presheaves do not provide the means to deduce global properties
from the properties we find locally in the open sets of $X$. This
is where the idea of sheaves come in.

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{sheaf}$ on $X$ is a presheaf $F$ on $X$
which satisfies the following $\textbf{sheaf axiom:}$:
\begin{itemize}
\item If $(U_{i})$ is an open covering of an open set $U$, with $i\in I$
for some indexing set $I$, and if for each $i$ a section $s_{i}\in F(U_{i})$
is given such that for each pair $U_{j}$,$U_{k}$$\in(U_{i})$ of
the covering sets the restrictions of $s_{j}|_{U_{j}\cap U_{k}}=s_{k}|_{U_{j}\cap U_{k}}$,
then there exists a unique section $s\in F(U)$ such that $s|_{U_{i}}=s_{i}$
for each $i\in I$. 
\end{itemize}
\end{defn}

\begin{defn} $\mathbf{Sh}(X)$ is the full subcategory of $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}$,
whose objects are sheaves on $X$ and morphisms being natural transformations.
\end{defn}

\begin{prop} The sheaf axioms imply that any sheaf has exactly one
section of the empty set. \end{prop}

\begin{proof}The empty set $\emptyset$ can be written as the union
of an empty family (that is, the indexing set $I$ is $\emptyset$).
The condition given for the sheaf property is vacuously true. So there
must exist a unique section in $F(\emptyset)$. \end{proof}

\begin{ex}Show that the sheaf property can be stated in a more categorical
way like this: the following diagram is an equalizer:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} F(U) \arrow[r] & \prod _i F(U_i ) \arrow[r, shift left] \arrow[r,shift right] & \prod _{i,j} F(U_i \cap U_j ) \end{tikzcd} \end{center}

\end{ex}


\subsubsection{Examples of Sheaves}

\begin{example} Given a topological space $X$, a point $x\in X$,
and a set $S$, the skyscraper sheaf $skyscr_{x}(S)$ is defined as
follows: 
\[
skyscr_{x}(S)(U)=\begin{cases}
S & \emph{if x\ensuremath{\in}U}\\
* & \emph{otherwise}
\end{cases}
\]


\begin{rem} The skyscraper sheaf $skyscr_{x}(S)$ is the direct image
of $S$ under the geometric morphism $x:\mathbf{Set}\to\mathbf{Sh}(X)$
which defines the point of a topos given by $x\in X$.

\end{rem}

\end{example}

\begin{example} Let $X=\{a,b,c\}$ be given the discrete topology
so that every subset of $X$ is open. Sheaves on $X$ are completely
determined by their values on the singleton sets. Namely, if $F$
is a sheaf which takes values $\{a\}\to A$, $\{b\}\to B$, $\{c\}\to C$
for some sets $A,B,C$, then $F$ will take this diagram: 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  &   \{ a,b,c \}  \\  \{ a,b \}  \arrow[ur] &  \{ a,c \}  \arrow[u] & \{ b,c \} \arrow[lu] \\  \{ a \} \arrow[u] \arrow[ur] & \{ b \} \arrow[ul] \arrow[ur]  &  \{ c \}  \arrow[u] \arrow[lu] \\ &  \emptyset  \arrow[u] \arrow[lu] \arrow[ru] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

and turn it into this diagram:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  &   A \times B \times C  \arrow[dl] \arrow[d] \arrow[dr] \\  A \times B  \arrow[d] \arrow[dr] &  A \times C  \arrow[dl] \arrow[dr] & B \times C \arrow[dl] \arrow[d] \\  A \arrow[dr]  & B \arrow[d]  &  C  \arrow[dl] \\ &  \{ 0 \} \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\end{example}

\begin{example}

Let $X=\{a,b,c\}$ with the topology given as in example 1.10, where
the open sets are highlighted in red:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  &  \textcolor{red}{ \{ a,b,c \} } \\ \textcolor{red}{ \{ a,b \} } \arrow[ur] & \textcolor{red}{ \{ a,c \} } \arrow[u] & \{ b,c \} \arrow[lu] \\ \textcolor{red}{ \{ a \}} \arrow[u] \arrow[ur] & \{ b \} \arrow[ul] \arrow[ur]  & \textcolor{red}{ \{ c \} } \arrow[u] \arrow[lu] \\ & \textcolor{red}{ \emptyset } \arrow[u] \arrow[lu] \arrow[ru] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

This time a sheaf $F$ on $X$ is completely determined by its values
on$\{a\}$, $\{c\}$, and $\{a,b\}$. So let's say $F$ takes values
$\{a\}\to A$, $\{c\}\to C$, and $\{a,b\}\to B$. The sheaf $F$
will take this diagram: 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  &   \{ a,b,c \}  \\  \{ a,b \}  \arrow[ur] &  \{ a,c \}  \arrow[u] &  \\  \{ a \} \arrow[u] \arrow[ur] &&  \{ c \}  \arrow[lu] \\ &  \emptyset  \arrow[lu] \arrow[ru] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

and turn it into this diagram:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  &  B \times C  \arrow[dl] \arrow[d] \\  B  \arrow[d] &  A \times C  \arrow[dl] \arrow[dr]  \\  A \arrow[dr]  & &  C  \arrow[dl] \\ &  \{ 0 \}  \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\end{example}

$\textbf{Note:}$ It may seem as if sheaves take colimits to limits.
This isn't true for all diagrams! However, if our diagram is a collection
of open subsets that is closed under finite intersections, then will
take a colimit of this diagram, namely the union of this collection,
to a limit of the corresponding diagram in $\mathbf{Set}$. 


\subsubsection{Presheaves that are not Sheaves}

\begin{example} Let $F$ be a presheaf on the real line $\mathbb{R}$,
defined as follows:
\[
F(U)=\begin{cases}
\{0,1\} & \emph{if U=\ensuremath{\mathbb{R}}}\\
\{0\} & otherwise
\end{cases}
\]


locally, this presheaf is just $\{0\}$, so where did this extra element
$1$ come from? It can't be a sheaf. It would, however, be a sheaf
if we got rid of the element $1$.

\end{example}

\begin{example} Let $F$ be the presheaf of continuous bounded functions
from $\mathbb{R}$ to $\mathbb{R}$. Why is this not a sheaf? Hint:
Try gluing a bunch of continuous bounded functions to form a continuous
unbounded function on $\mathbb{R}$. We can turn this thing into a
sheaf if we adjoin continuous unbounded functions. \end{example}

$\textbf{Note:}$ Notice in the previous two examples we either needed
to remove elements to turn a presheaf into a sheaf, or we needed to
adjoin elements to turn a presheaf into a sheaf. This process of removing
or adjoining elements of a presheaf to obtain a sheaf is known as
$\textbf{sheafification}$.


\subsubsection{Stalks}

In general, if for each $x\in X$, we can find the smallest neighborhood
containing $x$, say $U_{x}$, we can determine the sheaf completely
by computing the values of the sheaf on these open sets. The problem
is that the limit of the diagram which consists of all open neighborhoods
of $x$ may not exist, i.e. we may not have a smallest open neighborhood.
However, colimits do exist in $\mathbf{Set}$, and there's nothing
stopping from looking at colimits in the diagram of $F$-images of
neighborhoods of $x$. It turns out this is precisely what we need.

\begin{defn} Let $F$ be a presheaf on a topological space $X$.
For each $x\in X$, the collection $\{F(V)\mid x\in V\}$ of $F$-images
of neighborhoods of $x$, together with their associated restricting
maps, forms a diagram in $\mathbf{Set}$. The $\mathbf{stalk}$ of
$F$ at $x$, denoted $F_{x}$, is defined to be the colimit $\varinjlim _{x \in V} F(V)$
of this diagram. Explicitly, an equivalence relation $\sim_{x}$ is
defined on $\cup\{F(V)\mid x\in V\}$: if $s_{i}\in F(V_{i})$ and
$s_{j}\in F(V_{j})$ (where $V_{i}$ and $V_{j}$ are neighborhoods
of $x$), we put 

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccc}
$s_{i}\sim_{x}s_{j}$  & if and only if & $F_{k}^{i}(s_{i})=F_{k}^{j}(s_{j})$ & for some $x$-neighborhood $V_{k}\subseteq V_{i}\cap V_{j}$ \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\begin{rem} Thus, $s_{i}\sim_{x}s_{j}$ when they are ``locally
equal''.\end{rem}

\end{defn}

The elements in $F_{x}$ are called $\textbf{germs}$. This terminology
was also used when discussed various objects in slice categories.
Is there a connection? Yes, there is. And it's not just any old connection,
but in fact an adjunction! Stay tuned for that.


\subsection{$Set^{O(X)^{op}}$ as a topos}

Now we discuss the topos aspect to $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}$ 


\subsubsection{terminal object}

Easy exercise.


\subsubsection{pullback}

Easy exercise.


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

\begin{defn} Let $X$ be a topological space. Given an object $V\in\mathbf{O}(X)$,
a $V$-sieve, $S_{V}$, is a collection ${\cal C}$ of open subsets
of $V$ such that if $V\in C$ and $W$ is an open subset of $U$,
then $W\in{\cal C}$. \end{defn}

The classifying presheaf in the presheaf category $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}$
is defined as follows: $\Omega(V)$ is the set of all $V$-sieves.
The classifier arrow is a natural transformation $\top:1\to\Omega$,
which has components $\top_{V}:\{0\}\to\Omega(V)$ given by:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
 &  & \tabularnewline
$\top_{V}(0)=\mathbf{O}(V)$ &  & the largest $V$-sieve, i.e. the set of all open subsets of $V$.\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Given a monic arrow $\tau:F\to G$ of presheaves, with each $\tau_{V}$
being the inclusion $F(V)\hookrightarrow G(V)$, the character $\chi_{\tau}:G\to\Omega$
has components given by:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c}
\tabularnewline
$\chi_{V}(x)=\{U\subseteq V\mid G_{U}^{V}(x)\in F(U)$\tabularnewline
\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\begin{example} Let $X$ be finite topological space we considered
\hypertarget{topology1}{earlier}. Let's compute some sieves on it.
How many sieves are there on $\{a,b,c\}$? There are eight:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{X}=\{X,\{a,b\},\{a,c\},\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $X$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\{a,b\},\{a,c\}}=\{\{a,b\},\{a,c\},\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$  &  & generated by $\{a,b\}$ and $\{a,c\}$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\{a,c\}}=\{\{a,c\},\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $\{a,c\}$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\{a,b\}}=\{\{a,b\},\{a\},\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $\{a,b\}$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\{a\},\{c\}}=\{\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $\{a\}$ and $\{c\}$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\{a\}}=\{\{a\},\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $\{a\}$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\{c\}}=\{\{c,\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $\{c\}$\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
$S_{X}^{\emptyset}=\{\emptyset\}$ &  & generated by $\emptyset$ \tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

The superscript of $S$ denotes the generators of the sieve, and the
subscript denotes the object the sieve is on. Is this a sheaf? The
answer no: The open sets $\{a,c\}$ and $\{a,b\}$ cover $X$, (i.e.
$X\subseteq\{a,c\}\cup\{a,b\}$). We also have $\{a,c\}\cap\{a,b\}=\{a\}$.
Let's compute $\Omega(\{a\})$, $\Omega(\{a,c\})$, and $\Omega(\{a,b\})$:
\[
\Omega(\{a\})=\{S_{\{a\}}^{\{a\}},S_{\{a\}}^{\emptyset}\}
\]
\[
\Omega(\{a,c\})=\{S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a,c\}},S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a\},\{c\}},S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{c\}},S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a\}},S_{\{a,c\}}^{\emptyset}\}
\]
\[
\Omega(\{a,b\})=\{S_{\{a,b\}}^{\{a,b\}},S_{\{a,b\}}^{\{a\}},S_{\{a,b\}}^{\emptyset}\}
\]


Since $S_{\{a,b\}}^{\{a,b\}}$ is defined on $\{a,b\}$ and restricts
to $S_{\{a\}}^{\{a\}}$ on $\{a\}$, and $S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a,c\}},S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a\},\{c\}},S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a\}}$
are all defined on $\{a,c\}$ and restrict to $S_{\{a\}}^{\{a\}}$
on $\{a\}$ , then if $\Omega$ were a sheaf, we should be able to
glue these together to form three unique elements in $\Omega(X)$.
But there are several problems we run into. For one, $S_{\{a,b\}}^{\{a,b\}}$
and $S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a,c\}}$ can glue together to form $S_{X}^{\{a,b\},\{a,c\}}$
or $S_{X}^{X}$, which is not unique. Also, we can't even glue $S_{\{a,b\}}^{\{a,b\}}$
and $S_{\{a,c\}}^{\{a\},\{c\}}$ together, it doesn't exist. These
sieves generated by more than one open set are causing us problems.
If we were to remove them, would we then get a sheaf? Indeed we would.

\end{example}


\subsection{$Sh(X)$ as a topos}

Now we discuss the topos structure of $\mathbf{Sh}(X)$ 


\subsubsection{terminal object}

Easy exercise.


\subsubsection{pullback}

Easy exercise.


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

The classifying sheaf is defined as follows: $\Omega_{j}(U)$ is the
set of all open subsets of $U$. This is also the same thing as the
set of all $U$-sieves generated by a single element! The classifier
arrow is a natural transformation $\top:1\to\Omega$, which has components
$\top_{U}:\{0\}\to\Omega_{j}(U)$ given by:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
 &  & \tabularnewline
$\top_{U}(0)=\mathbf{O}(V)$ &  & the largest $U$-sieve, i.e. the set of all open subsets of $V$.\tabularnewline
 &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Now, given a monic arrow $\tau:F\to G$ of presheaves, with each $\tau_{U}$
being the inclusion $F(U)\hookrightarrow G(U)$, the character $\chi_{\tau}:G\to\Omega$
has components given by:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c}
\tabularnewline
$(\chi_{\tau})_{U}(x)=\{V\subseteq U\mid G_{V}^{U}(x)\in F(U)$\tabularnewline
\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\begin{example}

\hypertarget{classifyingsheaf}{}Let $X$ be the finite topological
space we considered \hyperlink{topology1}{earlier}. $\Omega_{j}(U)$
is the set of open subsets of $U$. In our case, we have:

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(\emptyset)=\{\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(\{a\})=\{\{a\},\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(\{c\})=\{\{c\},\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(\{a,b\})=\{\{a,b\},\{a\},\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(\{a,c\})=\{\{a,c\},\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(X)=\{X,\{a,b\},\{a,c\},\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

\end{example}

Now we ask, what is the relationship between $\Omega_{j}$ and $\Omega$?
To answer this, we first need to define two natural transformations
$j:\Omega\to\Omega$, $e:\Omega_{j}\to\Omega$. 

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} V \arrow[from=d, hookrightarrow] && \Omega ( V ) \arrow[r, "j _{ V }"] \arrow[d, " \Omega ^{V} _{U} " swap] & \Omega (V) \arrow[d, "\Omega ^{V} _{U}"] \\ U && \Omega (U) \arrow[r, "j _{U}" swap]  & \Omega (U) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}let
$e:\Omega_{j}\to\Omega$ be the natural transformation which has components
$e_{V}(\mathbf{O}(V))\to\Omega(V)$ given by:
\[
e_{V}(U)=\mathbf{O}(U)=S_{V}^{U}
\]


So $e$ acts like an inclusion. Using our example above, we have $e_{X}(X)=S_{X}^{X}$,
$e_{X}(\{a,b\})=S_{X}^{\{a,b\}}$, and so on. Every sieve that is
generated by a single open set is mapped to, and conversely every
open set is mapped to a sieve generated by one open set. This gives
us a one-one correspondence between sieves generated by a single open
set (also known as $\textbf{principal sieves}$, and open sets. We
are now ready to state the relationship between $\Omega_{j}$ and
$\Omega$.

\begin{prop} The following diagram is an equalizer $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}$:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}  \Omega _j \arrow[r, " e "]  & \Omega \arrow[r, "1 _{ \Omega } ", shift left =1] \arrow[r, "j", shift right = 1, swap] & \Omega \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\end{prop}


\subsection{Sheaves with Algebraic Structure}

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{presheaf \ensuremath{P} of abelian groups}$
on a space $X$ is defined to be an abelian group object in $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}$.
\end{defn}

Thus, a presheaf of abelian groups consists of natural transformations:

``group multiplication'' $m:P\times P\to P$

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} V \arrow[from=d, hookrightarrow] && P ( V ) \times P ( V ) \arrow[r, " m_V "] \arrow[d, " P ^{V} _{U} \times P ^{V} _{U} " swap] & P(V) \arrow[d, "P ^{V} _{U}"] \\ U && P ( U ) \times P ( U ) \arrow[r, " m_U " swap]  & P(U) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\begin{flushleft}
An ``inclusion of identity element'' $e:1\to P$: 
\par\end{flushleft}

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} V \arrow[from=d, hookrightarrow] && \{ 0 \} \arrow[r, " e_V "] \arrow[d, " ! " swap] & P(V) \arrow[d, "P ^{V} _{U}"] \\ U && \{ 0 \} \arrow[r, " e_U " swap]  & P(U) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\begin{flushleft}
An ``inverse operation'' $inv:P\to P$:
\par\end{flushleft}

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} V \arrow[from=d, hookrightarrow] && P(V) \arrow[r, " inv_V "] \arrow[d, " P ^V _U " swap] & P(V) \arrow[d, "P ^{V} _{U}"] \\ U && P(U) \arrow[r, " inv_U " swap]  & P(U) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}


\section{Functor Categories}

With these examples in mind, we now describe the topos structure of
$\mathbf{Set^{C}}$, where $\mathbf{C}$ is any small category.


\subsubsection{terminal object}

A terminal object in this category is the constant functor $1:\mathbf{C\to Set}$,
which takes every object $c\in\mathbf{C}$ to the terminal object
in $\mathbf{Set}$, $\{0\}$, and it takes every morphism $f:c\to c'$
in $\mathbf{C}$ to the identity morphism $id_{\{0\}}\{0\}\to\{0\}$. 


\subsubsection{pullback}

All limits and colimits in $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{C}}$ are defined
componentwise (hence, pullbacks are defined componentwise in particular).
So given $\tau:F\to H$ and $\sigma:G\to H$, for each object $c\in\mathbf{C}$,
form the pullback of:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} Z(c) \arrow[d," \lambda _c " swap] \arrow[r," \mu _c "] & G(c) \arrow[d," \sigma _c "] \\ F(c) \arrow[r," \tau _c " swap] & H(c) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

in $\mathbf{Set}$ of the components $\tau_{c}$ and $\sigma_{c}$.
Now, the assignment $c$ to $Z(c)$ for each object $c$ establishes
a functor $\mathbf{C\to Set}$. Given an arrow $f:c\to c'$ in $\mathbf{C}$,
we get a unique function $Z(f):Z(c)\to Z(c')$ which comes from the
cube:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[row sep=scriptsize, column sep=scriptsize] & Z(c) \arrow[dl," Z(f) " swap] \arrow[rr," \mu _c "] \arrow[dd," \lambda _c " near end, swap] & & G(c) \arrow[dl," G(f) " swap] \arrow[dd, " \sigma _c "] \\ Z(c') \arrow[rr, crossing over, " \mu _{c'} " near end] \arrow[dd," \lambda _{c'} " swap] & & G(c') \\ & F(c) \arrow[dl, " F(f) " near start, swap] \arrow[rr," \tau _c " near start] & & H(c) \arrow[dl, " H(f) " near start] \\ F(c') \arrow[rr, " \tau _{c'} " swap] & & H(c') \arrow[from=uu, crossing over, " \sigma _{c'} " near start]\\ \end{tikzcd}\end{center} 

The $\lambda_{c}$'s and $\mu_{c}$'s are components for the natural
transformations $\lambda:Z\to F$ and $\mu:Z\to G$ that make the
following diagram a pullback in $\mathbf{Set^{C}}$:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} Z \arrow[d," \lambda  " swap] \arrow[r," \mu  "] & G \arrow[d," \sigma "] \\ F \arrow[r," \tau " swap] & H \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

Compare this with the arrow category of $\mathbf{Set}$.


\subsubsection{subobject classifier}

\begin{defn} A $c$-cosieve is a collection $S_{c}$ of arrows with
common domain $c$, which is closed under left composition, i.e. if
$f:c\to c'$ is in $S_{c}$ and $g:c'\to c''$ is any other arrow,
then $g\circ fc\to c''$ is in $S_{c}$. \begin{rem} Equivalently,
a $c$-cosieve is a subfunctor of $Hom(c,-)$. Prove this.\end{rem}

\end{defn}

\begin{example}

What do $c$-sieves look like in the poset category $\mathbf{3}$?
There are three $2$-sieves: $S_{2}=\{0\to2\}$, $S_{2}^{'}=\{0\to2,1\to2\}$,
and $S_{2}^{''}=\{0\to2,1\to2,2\to2\}$ 

\end{example}

\begin{example}

What do sieves look like in a monoid $M$ (i.e. a category with one
object $\bullet$)? A sieve $S_{\bullet}$ on the object $\bullet$
is simply a left ideal in the set of arrows in $M$ . 

\end{example}

Define $\Omega(c)$ to be the set of all $c$-cosieves, and for an
arrow $f:c\to c'$ in $\mathbf{C}$, let $\Omega(f):\Omega(c)\to\Omega(c')$
be the function that takes the $c$-sieve $S_{c}$ to the $c'$-sieve
$\{g:c'\to c''\mid g\circ f\in S_{c}\}$. Notice that if $f\in S_{c}$,
then $\Omega(f)$ sends $S_{c}$ to Hom$(c,-)$ (compare this with
$M$-set). Now, define $\top:1\to\Omega$ to be the natural transformation
that has components $\top_{c}:\{0\}\to\Omega(c)$ given by $\top_{c}(0)=Hom(c,-)$
(the largest $c$-sieve). To see how $\top$ works, suppose $F\to G$
is a monic arrow in $\mathbf{Set^{C}}$. We may assume it is an inclusion
$F(c)\hookrightarrow G(c)$ at each component. Now the character $\chi_{\tau}$
of $\tau$ is to be a natural transformation with the component $(\chi_{\tau})_{c}$
a set function from $G(c)$ to $\Omega(c)$. Thus, $(\chi_{\tau})_{c}$
assigns to each $x\in G(c)$, a $c$-sieve $(\chi_{\tau})_{c}(x)$.
Now, when is an arrow $f:c\to c'$ in $(\chi_{\tau})_{c}(x)$? Given
