such an $f$, we have a commutative diagram: \begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} F(c) \arrow[d," F(f) " swap] \arrow[r," \tau _c  " hookrightarrow] & G(c) \arrow[d," G(f) "] \\ F(c') \arrow[r," \tau _b " swap, hookrightarrow] & G(c') \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

$f$ is in $(\chi_{\tau})_{c}(x)$ if and only if $G(f)$ maps $x$
into $F(c')$. Thus, $(\chi_{\tau})_{c}(x)=\{f:c\to c'\mid G(f)(x)\in F(c')\}$.
More generally, assuming only that $\tau_{c}$ is a function, perhaps
not an inclusion, we put
\[
(\chi_{\tau})_{c}(x)=\{f:c\to c'\mid G(f)(x)\in\tau_{c}(F(c'))\}
\]



\subsection{Representable Functors}

Recall, the functor $Hom(c,-):\mathbf{C\to Set}$, which takes an
object $d\in\mathbf{C}$ to the set of all morphisms from $c$ to
$d$, and takes a morphism $f:d\to d'$ to a function $Hom(c,f):Hom(c,d)\to Hom(c,d')$,
sending $g:c\to d$ to $f\circ g:c\to d\to d'$:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} d \arrow[d, "f", swap] && Hom(c,d) \arrow[d, " Hom(c \text{,} f)", swap] & g \arrow[d, mapsto] \\ d' && Hom(c,d')  & f \circ g \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\begin{example} Let $\mathbf{O}(X)$ be the poset category with open
sets as objects and inclusions are morphisms. $Hom(U,-)$ is easy
to describe:
\[
Hom(U,V)=\begin{cases}
0 & \mbox{ if }U\nsubseteq V\\
1 & \mbox{ if }U\subseteq V
\end{cases}
\]


and given an inclusion $i:W\hookrightarrow V$
\[
Hom(U,i):\{U\hookrightarrow W\}\to\{U\hookrightarrow W\hookrightarrow V\}=\{U\hookrightarrow V\}
\]


This is actually a sheaf, can you see why? 

\end{example}

\begin{lemma}Let $F$ be a functor from a category $\mathbf{C}$
to $\mathbf{Set}$. The set of natural transformations from Hom$(c,-)$
to $F$ are in one-to-one correspondence with the elements of $F(c)$,
i.e.
\[
\mbox{Nat}(\mbox{Hom}(c,-),F)\cong F(c)
\]


\end{lemma}

\begin{proof} The idea is that any natural transformation $\tau:Hom(c,-)\to F$
is completely determined by $\tau_{c}(id_{c})$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} c \arrow[d, "f", swap] && Hom(c,c) \arrow[r, " \tau _c "] \arrow[d, " Hom(c \text{,} f)", swap] & F(c) \arrow[d, " F(f) "] \\ d && Hom(c,d) \arrow[r, "\tau _{d}", swap]  & F(d) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

For each $d\in\mathbf{C}$, we must show how $\tau_{d}$ is completely
determined by$\tau_{c}(id_{c})$. The commutative diagram above tells
us that $\tau_{d}(f)=F(f)(\tau_{c}(id_{c}))$. So as soon as we assign
a value to $\tau_{c}(id_{c})$, then $\tau_{d}(f)$ is determined
for all objects $d$ and morphisms $f:c\to d$.

\end{proof}


\part{Sheaves as Etale Spaces}


\section{An equivalence of categories}

We start with the main theorem:

\begin{theorem} For any space $X$ there is a pair of adjoint functors

\begin{center} \begin{tikzcd}  \mathbf{Top} / X \arrow[r, " \Gamma ", shift left = 1] & \mathbf{Set}^{O(X)^{op}} \arrow[l, " \varLambda ", shift left=1] \end{tikzcd} \end{center}

where $\Gamma$ assigns to each object in $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Top}/X$,
the sheaf of all sections $F_{p}$ of $p$, while its left adjoint
$\varLambda$ assigns to each preasheaf $F$, the etale space $(B_{F},p_{F})$.
There are natural transformations

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
$\eta_{F}:F\to\Gamma\varLambda F$ &  & $\epsilon_{B}:\varLambda\Gamma B\to B$\tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

for a presheaf $F$ and an object $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Top}/X$ , which
are unit and counit making $\varLambda$ a left adjoint for $\Gamma$.
If $F$ is a sheaf, $\eta_{F}$ is an isomorphism, while if $B$ is
etale, $\epsilon_{B}$ is an isomorphism.

\end{theorem}

We will 


\subsubsection{From $\mathbf{Top}/X$ to $\mathbf{Sh}(X)$ }

We are now ready to discuss the relationship between sheaves and etale
spaces. Given an object $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Top}/X$, we can associate
a sheaf $F_{p}$ as follows:

\begin{center}
$F_{p}(U)=\{s\mid s$ is a section of $p$ defined on $U$$\}$ 
\par\end{center}

\hfill \break \hfill \break

\begin{tikzpicture} \draw [decorate,decoration={brace,amplitude=10pt},xshift=-4pt,yshift=0pt] (2.5,4) -- (2.5,7.2) node [black,midway,xshift=-1.2cm] (B)  {\LARGE $F_p \text(U) $}; \node (S) at (1,-.3) {\LARGE $X$}; \node (S'') at (3.6,-.3) {\LARGE $U$}; \node (S') at (0.2,7) {\LARGE $B$}; \node (z') at (7,0) {\LARGE $)$}; \node (z) at (3,0) {\LARGE $($}; \node (y) at (5,1) {}; \node (y') at (5,3) {}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(3.2,7)(4,7.1)(5,6.9)(6,7.1)(6.8,7)(6.8,7)(6,7.1)(5,6.9)(4,7.1)(3.2,7)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(3.2,6)(4,5.8)(5.5,6.2)(6.8,6)(6.8,6)(5.5,6.2)(4,5.8)(3.2,6)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(3.2,5)(5,4.8)(6.8,5)(6.8,5)(5,4.8)(3.2,5)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(3.2,4)(5,4.2)(6.8,4)(6.8,4)(5,4.2)(3.2,4)}; \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(1,0)(9,0)(9,0)(1,0)};  \draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(0,4)(10,4)(10,7.5)(0,7.5)} ;  \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (y') edge[] node[right] {} (y); \end{tikzpicture} 

\hfill \break \hfill \break

For an inclusion $U\hookrightarrow V$, $F_{pU}^{V}$ is the obvious
restriction map that assigns to each section $s:V\to B$, its restriction
$s|_{U}:U\to B$ to $U$. $F_{p}$ is called the $\textbf{sheaf of sections of \ensuremath{p}}$.
We need to check that this is indeed a sheaf, and not just a presheaf,
which certainly isn't obvious. 

\begin{prop} $F_{p}$ is a sheaf. \end{prop}

\begin{proof}

Suppose $(U_{i})$ is an open covering of an open set $U$, with $i\in I$
for some indexing set $I$, and that for each $i$ a local section
$s_{i}\in F_{p}(U_{i})$ is given such that for each pair $U_{j}$,$U_{k}$$\in(U_{i})$
of the covering sets the restrictions of $s_{j}|_{U_{j}\cap U_{k}}=s_{k}|_{U_{j}\cap U_{k}}$.
We need to show that there exists a unique section $s\in F(U)$ such
that $s|_{U_{i}}=s_{i}$ for each $i\in I$. We can construct a unique
$s$ like this: if $x\in U$, choose some $U_{i}$ that has $x\in U_{i}$,
and set $s(x)=s_{i}(x)$. This isn't as obvious as it looks. We need
to check a few things:
\begin{itemize}
\item $\textbf{Why is it well defined?}$
\end{itemize}
Whenever you make a construction where you have to choose something,
you always need to check and see if your construction is well-defined.
In the construction we just made, we chose an open neighborhood of
$x$. Now it's easy to see that this choice is irrelevant since we
could have chosen another open neighborhood $U_{j}$ of $x$, and
set $s(x)=s_{j}(x)$, and because $s_{i}=s_{j}$ on $U_{i}\cap U_{j}$,
we'd obtain the same value. This is a basic example of what is called
a $\textbf{gluing construction}$. In more general contexts, gluing
constructions will look very similar to what we just did. Namely,
there will be a pair $(s_{i},U_{i})$, where $(U_{i})$ covers $U$,
however the equality between $s_{i}$ and $s_{j}$ may be replaced
with an equivalence, a group action, or maybe something even more
general.
\begin{itemize}
\item $\textbf{Why is \ensuremath{s} continuous?}$
\end{itemize}
Because given an open subset$V$ of $B$, $s^{-1}(V)=\bigcup_{i}s_{i}^{-1}(V)$,
hence $s^{-}(V)$ is open. 
\begin{itemize}
\item $\textbf{Why is \ensuremath{s} unique?}$
\end{itemize}
The uniqueness of $s$ comes from how we constructed it in the first
place, for if $t:U\to B$ has $t|U_{i}=s_{i}$ for all $i\in I$,
then $t=s$. 

\end{proof}

Let $k:(A,q)\to(B,p)$ be an arrow in $\mathbf{Top}/X$. For each
open set $U$, define $k_{U}:F_{q}(U)\to F_{p}(U)$ to be the function
that maps a section $s\in F_{q}(U)$ to $k\circ s$. The maps $k_{U}$
are the components of a natural transformation from $F_{q}\to F_{p}$.
Thus, we have constructed a functor $\Gamma:\mbox{\ensuremath{\mathbf{Top}}}/X\to\mathbf{Sh}(X)$. 


\subsubsection{From $\mathbf{Set^{O(X)^{op}}}$ to $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$}

The functor from $\varLambda:\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}\to\mathbf{Etale}(X)$
is constructed using the idea of the stalk $F_{x}$ of a presheaf
$F$ at a given point $x$. We remind the reader that elements in
the stalk space $F_{x}$ are equivalence classes $[s]_{x}=\{t\mid s\sim_{x}t\}$,
where the equivalence relation $\sim_{x}$ is defined on $\cup\{F(V)\mid x\in V\}$:
if $s_{i}\in F(V_{i})$ and $s_{j}\in F(V_{j})$ (where $V_{i}$ and
$V_{j}$ are neighborhoods of $x$), we put 

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccc}
$s_{i}\sim_{x}s_{j}$  & if and only if & $F_{k}^{i}(s_{i})=F_{k}^{j}(s_{j})$ & for some $x$-neighborhood $V_{k}\subseteq V_{i}\cap V_{j}$ \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

We will conveniently write elements in $F_{x}$ like this: $(x,[s]_{x})$.
Now, suppose $F$ is a presheaf on $X$. We can construct an local
homeomorphism $p_{F}:B_{F}\to X$ as follows: First set $B_{F}=\bigcup_{x}F_{x}$,
and let $p_{F}$ be the obvious projection map. For each open subset
$V$ of $X$ and $s\in F(V)$, let $[s,V]=\{(x,[s]_{x})\mid x\in V\}$.
The collection of all $[s,V]$ generates a topology on $B_{F}$, making
$p_{F}$ a local homeomorphism. 

\begin{example} Let $X$ be the finite topological space we considered
\hyperlink{topology1}{earlier}. We constructed the classifying sheaf
$\Omega_{j}$ in this \hyperlink{classifyingsheaf}{example}. Let's
compute the stalk of this sheaf at point $b$. We know that they need
to consist of equivalence classes like this: $[s]_{b}$, where $s$
is a section defined on some open set containing $b$. Since every
element in $\Omega)_{j}(\{a,b\})$ is a restriction of an element
in $\Omega_{j}(X)$, we can choose representatives of this equivalence
class in $\Omega_{j}(X)$, so given that

\begin{center}
$\Omega_{j}(X)=\{X,\{a,b\},\{a,c\},\{a\},\{c\},\emptyset\}$
\par\end{center}

It's easy to check that we have three elements: 
\[
X\sim_{b}\{a,b\}
\]
\[
\{a\}\sim_{b}\{a,c\}
\]
\[
\emptyset\sim_{b}\{c\}
\]


We already compute this earlier though. We also said from earlier
that the collection of sets $[U,V]$ where $U,V$ are open and $U\subseteq V$
generate a topology on $B_{\Omega_{j}}$, which is the same thing
as saying $[s,V]$ generates a topology on $B_{\Omega_{j}}$, where
$s$ is a section on $V$. Notice that the global sections of our
classifying sheaf $\Omega_{j}$ are all open subsets of $X$. 

\end{example}

\begin{example} Now let's sheafify the classifying presheaf $\Omega$
in $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbf{O}(X)^{op}}$ on $X$. Let's compute the
stalk of this presheaf at point $b$. We know that they need to consist
of equivalence classes like this: $[s]_{b}$, where $s$ is a section
defined on some open set containing $b$. Since every element in $\Omega(\{a,b\})$
is a restriction of an element in $\Omega(X)$, we can choose representatives
of this equivalence class in $\Omega(X)$, so given that

\begin{center}
$\Omega(X)=\{S_{X}^{\{a,b,c\}},S_{X}^{\{a,b\}\{a,c\}},S_{X}^{\{a,c\}},S_{X}^{\{a,b\}},S_{X}^{\{a\}\{c\}},S_{X}^{\{a\}},S_{X}^{\{c\}},S_{X}^{\emptyset}\}$
\par\end{center}

It's easy to check that we have three elements:

\[
S_{X}^{\{a,b,c\}}\sim_{b}S_{X}^{\{a,b\}}\sim_{b}S_{X}^{\{a,b\}\{a,c\}}
\]
\[
S_{X}^{\{a\}}\sim_{b}S_{X}^{\{a,c\}}\sim_{b}S_{X}^{\{a\}\{c\}}
\]
\[
S_{X}\sim_{b}S_{X}^{\{c\}}
\]


For example, the reason we have $S_{X}^{\{a,b\}}\sim_{b}S_{X}^{\{a,b\},\{a,c\}}$
is because they both restrict to $S_{\{a,b\}}^{\{a,b\}}$ on $\{a,b\}$.
So the elements with two generators restrict to an element with one
generator on a small enough open set. Indeed, it can easily be shown
that $S_{X}^{\{U\},\{V\}}\sim_{x}S_{X}^{\{U\cup V\}}$ for two open
sets $U,V$. So the sheafification of the classifying presheaf is
``the same thing'' as the sheafification of the classifying sheaf. 

\end{example}


\subsubsection{co-unit}

Let $p:B\to X$ be any local homeomorphism, $F_{p}$ its sheaf of
sections, and $p_{F_{p}}:B_{F_{p}}\to X$ the associated sheaf of
germs. Define a map $k:B\to B_{F_{p}}$ as follow: If $b\in B$, there
exist a local section $s$ of $p$ through $b$, defined on an open
set $V$, i.e. $b\in s(V)$ (we proved this earlier). Let $k(b)=(f(b),[s]_{f(b)})$
be the germ of $s$ at $f(b)$. The definition of $k(b)$ does not
depend on which section through $b$ is chosen (we proved this earlier
too). This gives us the following commutative diagram:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[column sep=small] B \arrow[dr,"p" swap] \arrow[rr,"k"] && B_{F_{p}} \arrow[dl," p_{F_{p}} "] \\ & X \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

And $k$ is a $\mathbf{Etale}(X)$-arrow from $p$ to $p_{F_{p}}$,
in fact, it is an iso. 


\subsubsection{unit}

Define $\tau_{U}:F(U)\to F_{p_{F}}(U)$ by putting, for $s\in F(U)$,
$\tau_{U}(s)=s_{U}$, where $s_{U}:U\to A_{F}$ is defined by putting
$s_{U}(x)=(x,[s]_{x})$ for all $x\in U$...


\subsection{Geometric Morphism}

A continuous map of spaces, $f:X\to Y$, will induce functors in both
directions, forward and backward, on the associated categories of
sheaves. 

\begin{defn} Given a presheaf $F$ on $X$ and a continuous map $f:X\to Y$,
the pushforward of $F$ under $f$ is a sheaf $f_{*}F$ on $Y$ is
defined on open sets $U$ of $Y$ by: 
\[
(f_{*}F)(U)=F(f^{-1}U)
\]


Moreover, $f_{*}$ is a functor from $\mathbf{Sh}(X)$ to $\mathbf{Sh}(Y)$.
Given the natural transformation $\tau$:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} V && F( V ) \arrow[r, "\tau _V "] \arrow[d] & G( V ) \arrow[d, ] \\ U \arrow[u, hookrightarrow] && F( U ) \arrow[r, " \tau _U " swap]  & G( U) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

$f_{*}$ turns this into:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd}[column sep=large] f^{-1}(V) && F( f^{-1}(V) ) \arrow[r, "\tau _{f^{-1}(V)} "] \arrow[d] & G( f^{-1}(V) ) \arrow[d, ] \\ f^{-1}(U) \arrow[u, hookrightarrow] && F( f^{-1}(U) ) \arrow[r, " \tau _{f^{-1}(V)} " swap]  & G( f^{-1}(U) ) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\end{defn}

Now that we have defined the direct image of a presheaf $F$ under
$f$, let's try to define an pullback presheaf $f^{*}$. We could
try something like this:
\[
(f^{*}F)(U)=F(fU)
\]


we run into a problem though: $f(U)$ is not necessarily open. On
the other hand, given an object in $(B,p)\in\mathbf{Top}/Y$, and
a continuous map $f:X\to Y$, the pullback functor $f^{*}:\mathbf{Top}/Y\to\mathbf{Top}/X$
is easy to define. For example, the stalk over $x$ is given by $B_{f(x)}$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=1/2] 

%Nodes

\node[] (u) at (2.8,1.2) {\large $f^{-1}(U)$};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$x$] (y) at (5,1.6) {};


\node[] (u') at (22,1.2) {\large $U$};
\node[] (yy') at (19,4.7) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$f(x)$] (y') at (19,1.6) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$b$] (yyy') at (19,6) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$b'$] (yyyy') at (19,7.5) {};
\node[circle, fill=black, inner sep=1.5pt, label=below:$b''$] (yyyyy') at (19,9) {};
 


%Plots

\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(1,0)(9,0)(9,2)(5,2.5)(1,2)};   
  

\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates  {(15,0)(23,0)(23,2)(19,2.5)(15,2)};   
\draw plot [smooth cycle] coordinates {(18.5,5) (19.5,5) (19.5, 10) (18.5,10)}; 


%Arrows
  

\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (yy') edge[] node[right] {\LARGE $$} (y'); 

\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (yyy') edge[out=170,in=30] node[above] {$$} (y); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (yyyy') edge[out=170,in=30] node[above] {$$} (y); \draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}, dashed] (yyyyy') edge[out=170,in=30] node[above] {$$} (y); 
\draw[-{Straight Barb[length=5pt,width=5pt]}] (y) edge[out=10,in=170] node[above] {$$} (y'); 

\end{tikzpicture}\end{center} 

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{geometric morphism}$ $f:\mathbf{C\to\mathbf{D}}$
of elementary topoi $\mathbf{C}$ and $\mathbf{D}$, is a pair $(f^{*},f_{*})$
of functors of the form 

\begin{center} \begin{tikzcd}  \mathbf{C} \arrow[r, " f_{*} ", shift left = 1] & \mathbf{D} \arrow[l, " f^{*} ", shift left=1] \end{tikzcd} \end{center}

such that $f^{*}$ is left exact and left adjoint to $f_{*}$. $f^{*}$
is called the inverse image part, and $f_{*}$ the direct image part,
of the geometric morphism. 

\end{defn}

So $f^{*}$ preserves finite limits and arbitrary colimits.


\part{Grothendieck Pretopology}


\section{Motivation}

The fundamental group $\pi_{1}(X)$ of a space $X$ can be thought
of as a Galois (automorphism) group Gal$(\hat{X}/X)$, where $\hat{X}$
is the universal covering space of $X$. 

\begin{defn} \hypertarget{covering map}{}Assume $X$ is connected,
a continuous map $p:Y\to X$ is call a $\textbf{covering}$ if for
any $x\in X$, there is an open neighborhood $U$ of $x$ such that
$p^{-1}(U)$ is a disjoint union of open sets in $Y$, each of which
is mapped homeomorphically onto $U$ by $p$. More formally, the pullback
$Y\times_{X}U$ is a coproduct:
\[
Y\times_{X}U=U\amalg U\amalg U\cdots
\]
The set of homeomorphisms $\alpha:Y\to Y$ over $X$ such that $p\circ\alpha=p$
forms a group, Aut$(Y/X)$, called the group of covering transformations
of $p:Y\to X$. \end{defn}

\begin{example} Coverings of $S^{1}$. 
\begin{itemize}
\item Define $p_{n}:S^{1}\to S^{1}$ to be the function $p_{n}(z)=z^{n}$
where $n$ is a positive integer and we view $z$ as a complex number
with norm $1$. 
\item Define $p_{\infty}:\mathbb{R}^{1}\to S^{1}$ to be the function $p_{\infty}(x)=(\cos2\pi x,\sin2\pi x)$.
\end{itemize}
\end{example}

We now restrict our attention to connected covering spaces, since
a general covering space is a disjoint union of connected ones.

\begin{defn} A covering $p:Y\to X$ is called $\textbf{Galois}$
if for each $x\in X$ and each pair of lifts $\tilde{x}$, $\tilde{x}'$
of $x$ , there is a covering transformation taking $\tilde{x}$ to
$\tilde{x}'$. For a Galois covering $p:Y\to X$, we call Aut$(Y/X)$
the Galois group of $Y$ over $X$ and denote it by Gal$(Y/X)$ \end{defn}

Intuitively, a Galois covering is one with maximal symmetry, in analogy
with Galois extensions, which as splitting fields of polynomials,
can be considered \textquotedblleft maximally symmetric.\textquotedblright{}
Recall that the main theorem of Galois theory gives a bijective correspondence
between intermediate field extensions and subgroups of the Galois
group. There is a similar version of the main theorem for coverings,
which relates connected coverings of a given space $X$ and subgroups
of $\pi_{1}(X)$.

\begin{theorem} The induced map $p_{*}:\pi_{1}(Y,y)\to\pi_{1}(X,x)$
is injective, and there is a bijection 

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccc}
$\{$connected coverings $p:Y\to X\}$/isom.  & $\cong$ & $\{$subgroups of $\pi_{1}(X,x)\}$/conj. \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

with the property that $p:Y\to X$ is a Galois covering if and only
if $p_{*}(\pi_{1}(Y,y))$ is a normal subgroup of $\pi_{1}(X,x)$.
In this case, 

\begin{center}
Gal$(Y/X)\cong\pi_{1}(X,x)/p_{*}(\pi_{1}(Y,y))$. 
\par\end{center}

\end{theorem}

So the analogy between Galois coverings and Galois extensions clearly
involves some sort of dualization. Spaces over $X$ are epimorphisms
to $X$, while extensions of a field $K$ are monomorphisms from $K$.
In the category of spaces $Y\to X$, the product is the pullback $Y\times_{X}Y'\to X$,
the coproduct is the disjoint union $Y\amalg Y'\to X$. The category
of fields however, does not have duals of these operations, but if
we embed fields in the larger category of commutative rings, we do
get products and coproducts. The product of any indexed family of
rings $R_{i}$ is the cartesian product $\prod R_{i}$ with termwise
ring operations. The coproduct of two rings $R,S$ is the tensor product
$R\otimes S$. 

\begin{defn} The covering $p:\hat{X}\to X$ which corresponds to
the identity subgroup of $\pi_{1}(X,x)$ is called the $\textbf{universal covering}$
of $X$.\end{defn}

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline 
$\textbf{Galois Coverings}$ & $\textbf{Galois Extensions}$\tabularnewline
\hline 
\hline 
Spaces over $X$  & extensions of a field $K$\tabularnewline
\hline 
Product given by $Y\times_{X}Y'\to X$ & Product given by $\prod R_{i}$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
Coproduct given by $Y\amalg Y'\to X$ & Coproduct given by $R\otimes_{K}R'$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
$\pi_{1}(Y,y)$ & $Gal(N/K)$\tabularnewline
\hline 
factorizations $Y\to Y'\to X$  & extensions $K\to L\to N$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
subgroups of $\pi_{1}(Y,y)$ & subgroups of $Gal(N/K)$\tabularnewline
\hline 
$Y\times_{X}U=U\amalg U\amalg U\cdots$ & $L\otimes_{K}N\cong N[x]/(x-\alpha_{1})(x-\alpha_{2})\dots(x-\alpha_{n})$\tabularnewline
\hline 
monomorphism $U\to X$ ``splits'' covering space & splitting field $N$ splits extension $K\to L$.\tabularnewline
\hline 
 & \tabularnewline
\hline 
 & \tabularnewline
\hline 
 & \tabularnewline
\hline 
 & \tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

$L\otimes_{K}N\cong N[x]/(x-\alpha_{1})(x-\alpha_{2})\dots(x-\alpha_{n})$
example: $K=\mathbb{Q}$, $L=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})$, $N=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2},\zeta_{3})$
where $\zeta_{3}$ is a nontrivial cube root of unity (for example
$\zeta_{3}=\exp^{\frac{2\pi i}{3}}$). 


\section{Pretopologies}

\begin{defn}A $\emph{pretopology}$ on a category $\mathbf{C}$ is
an assignment to each object $c\in\mathbf{C}$, a collection $Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$
of sets of morphisms with codomain $c$, called covers of $c$, such
that:
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $f:c'\to c$ is an isomorphism, then $\{f:c'\to c\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$.
\item If $\{f_{i}:c_{i}\to c\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$, and for each $i$
we have $\{f_{j}^{i}:c_{j}^{i}\to c_{i}\}\in Cov(c_{i})$, then $\{f_{i}\circ f_{j}^{i}:c_{j}^{i}\to c\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$. 
\item If $\{f_{i}:c_{i}\to c\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$, and $g:c'\to c$,
then for each $i$, the pullback of $f_{i}$ along $g$ exists, and
$\{g_{i}:c'\times_{c}c_{i}\to c'\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c')$:
\end{enumerate}
\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} c' \times _c c_i \arrow[r] \arrow[d,"g_i " swap] & c_i \arrow[d, "f_i "] \\ c' \arrow[r, "g"] & c \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

The pair $(\mathbf{C},Cov_{\mathbf{C}})$ of the category is called
a $\emph{site}$.

\end{defn}

\begin{example}$(\mathbf{O}(X),Cov_{\mathbf{O}(X)})$ is a site,
where for open $U\in\mathbf{O}(X)$, $Cov_{\mathbf{O}(X)}(U)=\{U_{i}\mid U_{i}$
is open and $\bigcup\limits _{i}U_{i}=U\}$. \end{example}

\begin{example}

Consider the poset category $\mathbf{3}$, which looks like this:

\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} 0 \arrow[loop above, " id_0 " ] \arrow[r] & 1 \arrow[r] \arrow[loop above, " id_1 "] & 2 \arrow[loop above, "id_2 "]\end{tikzcd}\end{center}

Consider these collections of sets:



\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c}
$Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(2)$ & $\{$$\{2\to2\}$,$\{1\to2,2\to2\}$$\}$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
$Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(1)$ & $\{$$\{1\to1\}$,$\{1\to1,0\to1\}$,$\{0\to1\}$$\}$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
$Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(0)$ & $\{$$\{0\to0\}$$\}$ \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Is this a pretopology? No, because these collection of sets fail to
satisfy the second condition of our definition. We can turn this into
a pretopology by adding in some sets into $Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(2)$ like
this:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c}
$Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(2)$ & $\{$$\{2\to2\}$,$\{1\to2,2\to2\}$,$\{0\to2,2\to2\}$,$\{0\to2,1\to2,2\to2\}$$\}$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
$Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(1)$ & $\{$$\{1\to1\}$,$\{1\to1,0\to1\}$,$\{0\to1\}$$\}$ \tabularnewline
\hline 
$Cov_{\mathbf{3}}(0)$ & $\{$$\{0\to0\}$$\}$ \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

\end{example}

This is related to multicategories. For example, axiom 2 says add
in compositions in a multicategory.


\section{Sheaves on pretopologies}

Sheaves on a pretopology have a simple description. For each covering
family $\{f_{i}:c_{i}\to c\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$, the diagram
\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} F(c) \arrow[r] & \prod\limits_{i} F(c_i ) \arrow[r, shift left] \arrow[r,shift right] & \prod\limits_{i,j} F(c_i \prod _c c_j ) \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

must be an equalizer. Here's another way we can describe this. 

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccc}
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\begin{tikzcd} c_i \times _c c_j \arrow[d] \arrow[r] & c_j \arrow[d, " f_j "] \\ c_i \arrow[r, " f_i " swap] & c \end{tikzcd} &  &  &  & \begin{tikzcd} F( c_i \times _c c_j ) & F( c_j ) \arrow[l] \\ F( c_i ) \arrow[u] & F(c) \arrow[l,"F( f_i )"] \arrow[u, "F( f_x )" swap] \end{tikzcd}\tabularnewline
 &  &  &  & \tabularnewline
\end{tabular}
\par\end{center}

Given any cover $\{f_{i}:c_{i}\to c\}\in Cov_{\mathbf{C}}(c)$ of
$c$, and any selection of elements $x_{i}\in F(c_{i})$ that are
pairwise compatible, i.e. $F_{j}^{i}(c_{i})=F_{i}^{j}(c_{j})$, then
there is exactly one $x\in F(c)$ such that $F_{i}(c)=s_{i}$.

\begin{example}$(\mathbf{O}(X),Cov_{\mathbf{O}(X)})$ is a site,
where for open $U\in\mathbf{O}(X)$, $Cov_{\mathbf{O}(X)}(U)=\{U_{i}\mid U_{i}$
is open and $\bigcup\limits _{i}U_{i}=U\}$. \end{example}


\part{Logic}


\section{Origins in Algebraic Geometry}

In algebraic geometry, the relation between sets of polynomials and
their zero sets is given by an antitone Galois connection. Fix a natural
number $n$ and a field $\mathbb{K}$ and let ${\cal C}$ be the set
of all subsets of the polynomial ring $\mathbb{K}[x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}]$
ordered by inclusion $\subseteq$, and let B be the set of all subsets
of Kn ordered by inclusion \ensuremath{\subseteq}. If S is a set of
polynomials, define the variety of zeros as

\begin{defn}

Given a set $S$ of polynomials, define the $\textbf{variety of zeros}$
${\cal V}(S)$ as the set of common zeros of polynomials in $S$:

\[
{\cal V}(S)=\{x\in\mathbb{K}^{n}\mid f(x)=0\mbox{ for all }f\in S\}
\]


Given a subset $X$ of $\mathbb{K}[x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}]$, define
the $\textbf{ideal of polynomials}$ ${\cal I}(X)$ as the set of
all polynomials that vanish on $X$:
\[
{\cal I}(X)=\{f\in\mathbb{K}[x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}]\mid f(x)=0\mbox{ for all }x\in X\}
\]


\end{defn}

\begin{prop}

There is an adjunction between lattice of ideals $(\mathbf{I}(R),\subseteq)$
and the lattice of varieties $(\mathbf{V}(X),\subseteq)^{op}$:

\begin{center} \begin{tikzcd}  (I, \subseteq ) \arrow[r, " \Gamma ", shift left = 1] & \mathbf{Set}^{O(X)^{op}} \arrow[l, " \varLambda ", shift left=1] \end{tikzcd} \end{center}

\end{prop}
\[
X={\cal V}({\cal I}(X))\mbox{ and }I\subseteq{\cal I}({\cal V}(I))
\]


Given ideals $I,J\in\mathbf{I}(R)$, we have: 

\[
{\cal V}(I+J)={\cal V}(I)\cap{\cal V}(J)
\]
\[
{\cal V}(I\otimes J)={\cal V}(I\cap J)={\cal V}(I)\cup{\cal V}(J)
\]


In a noetherian ring we have primary decomposition:
\[
I=P_{1}\cap P_{2}\cap\dots\cap P_{k}
\]


The corresponding variety is:
\[
V(I)=V(P_{1})\cup V(P_{2})\cup\dots\cup V(P_{k})
\]


Using this adjunction, we can translate geometric concepts to algebraic
ones, and vice-versa. For example, a variety $X$ is $\textbf{irreducible}$,
i.e. it can not be written as a union $X=X_{1}\cup X_{2}$ of two
non-empty proper subvarieties $X_{1},X_{2}$ of $X$, if and only
if ${\cal I}(X)$ is a prime ideal.

\begin{defn} The $\textbf{radical}$ of and ideal $I$, denoted $\sqrt{I}$
is:
\[
\sqrt{I}=\{f\in R\mid f^{n}\in I\mbox{ for some }n\in\mathbb{N}\}
\]


\end{defn}


\section{Lattices}

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{distributive lattice}$ is a lattice $(L,\leq)$
that satisfies the distributive law, i.e. for all $a,b,c$ in the
lattice:
\[
a\wedge(b\vee c)=(a\wedge b)\vee(a\wedge c)\quad\forall a,b,c\in L
\]


\begin{rem} Notice that every distributive lattice is modular.

\end{rem}

\end{defn}

\begin{defn} An element $y$ in a lattice $(L,\leq)$ is said to
be a $\textbf{complement}$ of $x$ if:
\[
x\vee y=1\mbox{ and }x\wedge y=0
\]


\end{defn}

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{boolean algebra}$ is a distributive lattice
with the property that every element has a complement. 

\end{defn}

\begin{example} $(\mathbf{P}(X),\subseteq)$ is a complete boolean
algebra, with set inclusion $\subseteq$ being the partial order,
set intersection $\cap$ being meet, and set union $\cup$ being join.
Given a subset $S\subset X$, the lattice complement of $S$ is the
set complement $S^{c}=X\setminus S=\{x\in X\mid x\notin S\}$. The
initial object is $\emptyset$. The terminal object is $X$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture}

\draw [fill=red!30!white] (-4,-4) rectangle (4,4);
\draw [fill=green!0!white] (330:1.2) circle (2);


\node at (3.8,4.5) {\LARGE $X$};
\node at ( 90:3) {\LARGE $ S^c $}; 
\node at (330:2) { \LARGE $S$}; 
\end{tikzpicture}\end{center}

\end{example}

\begin{defn} A $\textbf{modular lattice}$ is a lattice $(L,\leq)$
that satisfies the self-dual condition:
\[
a\leq c\mbox{ implies }a\vee(b\wedge c)=(a\vee b)\wedge c\quad\forall a,b,c\in L
\]


\begin{rem} Notice that every distributive lattice is modular.

\end{rem}

\end{defn}

\begin{example} Smallest example of a non-modular lattice: 
\[
a\vee(b\wedge c)=a\vee0=x\neq c=1\wedge c=(a\vee b)\wedge c
\]


\begin{center}\begin{tikzcd} & 1 \\ c \arrow[ur] \\ && b \arrow[uul] \\ a \arrow[uu] \\ & 0 \arrow[ul] \arrow[uur] \end{tikzcd}\end{center}

\end{example}

\begin{defn} Given a commutative ring with identity $R$, let $\mathbf{I}(R)$
be the set of all ideals in $R$. 

\end{defn}

\begin{example} $(\mathbf{I}(R),\subseteq)$ is a complete modular
lattice, with ideal inclusion $\subseteq$ being the partial order,
the sum $+$ of ideals being join, and the $\cap$ intersection of
ideals being meet. The initial object is $\emptyset$. The terminal
object is $R$.

\end{example}

\begin{defn} If $A$ is a subset of a lattice $(L,\leq)$, then $z\in L$
is an $\textbf{upper bound}$ of $A$, denoted $A\leq z$, if $x\leq z$
whenever $x\in A$. If moreover, $z\leq y$ whenever $A\le y$, then
$z$ is a $\textbf{least upper bound}$ of $A$.

\end{defn}

\begin{defn} We say that $z$ is the $\textbf{greatest element}$
of $A$ if $z$ is a least upper bound of $A$ and also a member of
$A$. Thus, $A$ has a greatest element precisely when one of its
members is a least upper bound of $A$. 

\end{defn}

\begin{defn} If $(L,\leq)$ is a lattice and $x\in L$, then $y\in L$
is the $\textbf{pseudo complement}$ of $x$ if and only if $y$ is
the greatest element of $L$ disjoint from $x$, i.e. greatest element
of the set: 
\[
\{z\in L\mid x\wedge z=0\}
\]


If every member of $L$ has a pseudo complement, $L$ is called a
$\textbf{pseudo complemented lattice}$.

\end{defn}

\begin{example}

If $M$ is a monoid, then the lattice of left ideals $(L_{M},\subseteq)$
is a pseudo complemented lattice. Given a left ideal $I\in L_{M}$,
define $\lnot I=\{m\mid I:m=\emptyset\}$. Then $\lnot I$ is the
pseudo complement of $I$, since $J\subseteq\lnot I$ if and only
if $J\cap I=\emptyset$ for all left ideals $J\in L_{M}$. Let's show
this: First, we show that $\lnot I$ is an ideal. If $m\in\lnot I$,
then $n\cdot m$ must be in $\lnot I$ too. since if $k\in I:n\cdot m$,
then $k\cdot(n\cdot m)\in I$, but this means that $(k\cdot n)\cdot m\in I$,
which is a contradiction. Now we show $\lnot I\cap I=\emptyset$.
If $m\in\lnot I\cap I$, then $I:m=M$, which is a contradiction.
Finally, we show that $\lnot I$ is the greatest element of the set
of all left ideals disjoint from $I$. If $j\in J$ and $J\cap I=\emptyset$,
then $I:j=\emptyset$ ($J$ swallows everything up!). So $\lnot I$
contains all left ideals $J$ disjoint from $I$. 

\end{example}

\begin{example} If $X$ is a topological space, then the lattice
of open sets $(\mathbf{O}(X),\subseteq)$ is a pseudo complemented
lattice. Even though the set complement $X\setminus U$ is not necessarily
open, the interior $(X\setminus U)^{\circ},$ i.e. the largest open
set contained in $X\setminus U$, is. So, $(X\setminus U)^{\circ}$
is the pseudo complement of $U$ since have $V\subseteq(X\setminus U)^{\circ}$
if and only if $U\cap V=\emptyset$, for all open $V\in\mathbf{O}(X)$.
In this case, $(X\setminus U)^{\circ}$ is simply the union of all
open sets disjoint from $U$. Since arbitrary unions of open sets
are open, we are done. Notice that this is not the argument we used
for $(L_{M},\subseteq)$. 

\end{example}

\begin{defn}The notion of pseudo complement can be generalized by
replacing the initial object $0$ by some other object $y$, to obtain
the pseudo complement of $x$ $\textbf{relative}$ to $y$. This,
if it exists, is the greatest element of the set: 
\[
\{w\mid x\wedge w\leq y\}
\]


So, the pseudo complement of $x$ relative to $y$ is the greatest
element $z$ such that $x\wedge z\leq y$. 

\end{defn}

\begin{example} If $S,T\in(\mathbf{P}(X),\subseteq)$, then $S^{c}\cup T$
is the pseudo complement of $S$ relative to $T$.

\begin{center}\begin{tikzpicture}

\draw [fill=red!30!white] (-4,-4) rectangle (4,4);
\draw [fill=green!0!white] (330:1.2) circle (2);
\draw [fill=red!30!white] (210:1.2) circle (2);

\node at (3.8,4.5) {\LARGE $X$};
\node at ( 90:3) {\LARGE $S^{c} \cup T $}; 
\node at (210:2) {\LARGE $T$}; 
\node at (330:2) { \LARGE $S$}; 
\end{tikzpicture}\end{center}

\end{example}

\begin{example}If $I,J\in(L_{M},\subseteq)$, then the pseudo complement
of $I$ relative to $J$ is $\{m\mid I:m\subseteq J:m\}$. If $I\subseteq J$,
then the pseudo complement of $I$ relative to $J$ is $M$. If $I\cap J=\emptyset$,
then the pseudo complement of $I$ relative to $J$ contains $J$,
but is disjoint from $I$. 

\end{example}

\begin{example}If $U,V\in(\mathbf{O}(X),\subseteq)$, then the pseudo
complement of $U$ relative to $V$ is $((X\setminus U)\cup V)^{\circ}$.

\end{example}

\begin{defn} Given a lattice $(L,\leq)$, the pseudo complement of
$x$ relative to $y$, when it exists, is denoted $x\Rightarrow y$.
And if $x\Rightarrow y$ exists for every $x,y\in L$, then $L$ is
called a $\textbf{Heyting Algebra}$. We use the notation $(H,\leq)$
to denote a Heyting Algebra. We also define $\lnot:H\to H$ by setting
$\lnot x$ equal to $x\Rightarrow0$.

\end{defn}

\begin{ex} Check that this is the same definition as we gave in the
other set of notes, i.e. a Heyting Algebra is a poset that has finite
limits, finite colimits, and is cartesian closed.\end{ex}

\begin{prop} A Heyting Algebra is distributive. 

\end{prop}
